artifacts.name: Achilles
artifacts.description: Achilles, created by Hephaestus and said to be impenetrable. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Beowulf
artifacts.description: f Beowulf, a mail shirt made by Wayland the Smith. (Anglo-Saxon mythology)

artifacts.name: Örvar-Oddr
artifacts.description: rvar-Oddr, an impenetrable "silken mailcoat". (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Babr-e Bayan
artifacts.description: a suit of armor that Rostam wore in wars described in the Persian epic Shahnameh. The armor was invulnerable against fire, water and weapons. (Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Fafnir
artifacts.description: Coat of Chainmail, part of Fafnir's treasure which Sigurd took after he slew the dragon. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Green Armor
artifacts.description: protects the wearer from physical injuries. (Arthurian legend)

artifacts.name: Karna
artifacts.description: ha, the armor of Karna that was granted to him by his father Surya at birth. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Diomedes
artifacts.description: Diomedes, made of bronze, that Diomedes exchanged with the golden armor of Glaucus. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Rostam
artifacts.description: of Rostam, upon which was fixed the head of the white giant Div-e-Sepid, from the Persian epic Shahnameh. (Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Helm of Awe
artifacts.description: (also Helm of Terror or Ægishjálmr), an Icelandic magical stave. A physical object called "Helm of Terror" is referenced as one item Sigurd takes from the dragon Fafnir's hoard after he slays him in the Völsunga saga. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: dwarves
artifacts.description: jálmr, a concealing helmet of the dwarves. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Tarnhelm
artifacts.description: a magic helmet giving the wearer the ability to change form or become invisible. Used by Alberich in Der Ring des Nibelungen. (Continental Germanic mythology)

artifacts.name: Arthurian legend
artifacts.description: met of King Arthur, passed down to him from Uther Pendragon. (Arthurian legend)

artifacts.name: Sun Wukong
artifacts.description: 's magical headband, a magical headband which, once put on, can never be removed. With a special chant, the band will tighten and cause unbearable pain. (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Kappa
artifacts.description: 's plate (Kappa no sara), the easiest way to defeat a kappa is to make it spill the water from the sara on top of its head. The sara is filled with water that is the source of its power. (Japanese mythology)

artifacts.name: Cap of invisibility
artifacts.description: (also Helm of Darkness or Helm of Hades), which can turn the wearer invisible. In addition to its owner, the god of the underworld Hades, wearers of the cap in Greek myths include Athena, the goddess of wisdom; the messenger god Hermes, and the hero Perseus.

artifacts.name: Dionysus
artifacts.description: s diadem, a diadem given to her by her husband Dionysus that was made by Hephaestus as a wedding present.

artifacts.name: El Cid
artifacts.description: of El Cid, a shield which bears the image of a fierce shining golden dragon.[1]

artifacts.name: Svalinn
artifacts.description: a shield which stands before the sun and protects Earth from burning. If the shield were to fall from its frontal position, the mountains and seas would burn up. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Cú Chulainn
artifacts.description: shield of Cú Chulainn. (Irish mythology)

artifacts.name: Han Feizi
artifacts.description: 's shield, from a Chinese parable that tells of a man who was trying to sell a spear and a shield. When asked how good his spear was, he claimed it could pierce any shield. Then, when asked how good his shield was, he claimed it could defend from all spear attacks. When he was asked what would happen if his spear should strike his shield, the seller could not answer. This led to the idiom of "zìxīang máodùn" (自相矛盾, "from each-other spear shield"), or "self-contradictory". (Chinese folklore)

artifacts.name: Oba's shield, which she uses to cover her right ear. (Yoruba mythology)
Pridwen
artifacts.description: (also Wynebgwrthucher), the shield of King Arthur.

artifacts.name: Joseph of Arimathea
artifacts.description: Arimathea, according to Arthurian legend, was carried by three maidens to Arthur's castle where it was discovered by Sir Percival. In Perlesvaus he uses it to defeat the Knight of the Burning Dragon.

artifacts.name: Judas Maccabee
artifacts.description: s Maccabee, a red shield emblazoned with a golden eagle. According to Arthurian legend the same shield was later found and used by Gawain after he defeated an evil knight.

artifacts.name: Josephus of Arimathea
artifacts.description: white shield belonging to King Evalach. Josephus of Arimathea painted a red cross upon it with his own blood, which granted the owner heavenly protection. It was later won by Sir Galahad.

artifacts.name: Aegis
artifacts.description: Zeus' shield, often loaned to his daughter Athena, also used by Perseus. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Ajax
artifacts.description: ld of Ajax, a huge shield made of seven cow-hides with a layer of bronze. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Ancile
artifacts.description: the shield of the Roman god Mars. One divine shield fell from heaven during the reign of Numa Pompilius, the second king of Rome. He ordered eleven copies made to confuse would-be thieves. (Roman mythology)

artifacts.name: Shield of Achilles
artifacts.description: the shield that Achilles uses in his fight with Hector. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Shield of Aeneas
artifacts.description: the shield that Aeneas receives from Vulcan to aid in his war against Turnus.

artifacts.name: Shamba
artifacts.description: a, the shield of Shamba.

artifacts.name: Srivatsa
artifacts.description: the shield of Vishnu, said to be manifested in the god's chest.

artifacts.name: Járngreipr
artifacts.description: (Iron Grippers), a pair of iron gauntlets used by the god Thor. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Crown of Immortality
artifacts.description: represented in art first as a laurel wreath and later as a symbolic circle of stars. It appears in a number of Baroque iconographic and allegoric works of art to indicate the wearer's immortality. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse
artifacts.description: the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, Conquest, rides a white horse and a crown was given to him. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Woman of the Apocalypse
artifacts.description: the Woman of the Apocalypse is seen wearing a crown of twelve stars on her head. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Crown of thorns
artifacts.description: which was placed on the head of Jesus during his crucifixion. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Radiate crown
artifacts.description: (also Solar crown, Sun crown, Eastern crown or Tyrant's crown), a crown or other headgear symbolizing the sun or more generally powers associated with the sun.

artifacts.name: Corona Borealis
artifacts.description: (Northern Crown), the crown was considered to represent a crown given by Dionysus to Ariadne, after she was taken from the Athenian prince Theseus. When she wore the crown at her marriage to Dionysus, he placed it in the heavens to commemorate their wedding. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Corona Australis
artifacts.description: (Southern Crown), the crown has been associated with the myth of Bacchus and Stimula. Jupiter had impregnated Stimula, causing Juno to become jealous. Juno convinced Stimula to ask Jupiter to appear in his full splendor, which the mortal woman could not handle, causing her to burn. After Bacchus, Stimula's unborn child, became an adult and the god of wine, he honored his deceased mother by placing a wreath in the sky. (Roman mythology)

artifacts.name: Megingjörð
artifacts.description: (Power-belt), a magic belt worn by the god Thor. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Peter Stumpp
artifacts.description: 's magical belt, Peter claimed that the Devil had given him a magical belt or girdle, which enabled him to metamorphose into a werewolf. Removing the belt made him transform back to his human form. (German legend)

artifacts.name: Aphrodite
artifacts.description: 's Cestus, a magic girdle that enhanced the wearer's beauty and made others fall in love with the wearer. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Hippolyta
artifacts.description: Hippolyta, a girdle that was a symbol of Hippolyta's power over the Amazons, and given to her by Ares. Heracles' 9th Labor was to retrieve it. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Tyet
artifacts.description: the ancient Egyptian symbol of the goddess Isis. It seems to be called "the Knot of Isis" because it resembles a knot used to secure the garments that the Egyptian gods wore. (Egyptian mythology)

artifacts.name: Brynhildr
artifacts.description: Brynhildr, Siegfried takes her girdle which makes Brynhildr lose her supernatural strength. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Constantine
artifacts.description: onstantine, said to be made from the nails used during the crucifixion of Christ.

artifacts.name: Estonian mythology
artifacts.description: kirikindad were believed to have protective or magic powers. They are decorated with special patterns and are imbued with whispers and spells by the singing of the crafter making them. (Estonian mythology)

artifacts.name: Veil of Isis
artifacts.description: an artistic motif in which nature is personified as the goddess Isis covered by a veil, representing the inaccessibility of nature's secrets. Helena Blavatsky, in Isis Unveiled in 1877, used the metaphor for the spiritual truths that her Theosophical belief system hoped to discover, and modern ceremonial magic includes a ritual called the "Rending of the Veil" to bring the magician to a higher state of spiritual awareness. (Western esotericism)

artifacts.name: Veil of Veronica
artifacts.description: according to legend, was used to wipe the sweat from Jesus' brow as he carried the cross. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Cohuleen druith
artifacts.description: : or cochaillín draíochta is a special hat worn by merrows which enables them to travel between deep water and dry land. If they lose this cap, it is said that they will lose their power to return beneath the water. (Scottish folklore)

artifacts.name: petasos
artifacts.description: petasos (also Winged petasus): the winged traveler hat of the messenger god Hermes. The Roman equivalent is Mercury. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Cap of invisibility
artifacts.description: (also Cap of Hades): a cap that turns a person invisible (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Saci
artifacts.description: 's cap: the red cap of the Saci which is the said source of all his magical abilities, like appearing and disappearing at will, inhuman speed (despite having just one leg) and the power to create and ride dust devils. Those who want to capture a Saci must throw a sieve over a Saci's dust devil to bind it and give a chance to remove his cap, rendering him powerless. Then he could be locked inside a bottle granting his total obedience - but not his loyalty, since the creature would always try to trick his master into giving back his cap. (Brazilian mythology)

artifacts.name: Vanatühi
artifacts.description: ingernails, or küüntest kübar is a hat belonging to Vanatühi that makes the wearer invisible. (Estonian mythology)

artifacts.name: kimono
artifacts.description: mo (Feather Dress), a colored or feathered kimono of a tennin. Tennin are unable to fly without these kimono and thus will be unable to return to Heaven. (Japanese mythology)

artifacts.name: Velificatio
artifacts.description: a stylistic device used in ancient Roman art to frame a deity by means of a billowing garment. It represents "vigorous movement", an "epiphany", or "the vault of heaven", often appearing with celestial, weather, or sea deities. (Roman mythology)

artifacts.name: Coat of many colors
artifacts.description: the garment that Joseph owned, which was given to him by his father, Jacob. (Jewish mythology)

artifacts.name: Penelope
artifacts.description: 's burial shroud, which Odysseus's wife Penelope pretended to weave for her deceased father-in-law. She claimed that she would choose a suitor when the shroud was complete, but secretly unraveled it every night to delay the decision. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Devil
artifacts.description: 's green coat, given to a soldier by the Devil, who claims its pockets are always full of limitless money, as told in the tale Bearskin. (German fairy tale)

artifacts.name: 藕
artifacts.description: usībùyúnlǚ (藕絲步雲履; "[Lotus-root Thread] Cloud-stepping Boots" or "~Shoes"), made of lotus fiber, these are one of the treasures of the Dragon Kings; Ào Ming gives them to Sun Wukong in order to get rid of him when he acquires the Ruyi Jingu Bang. (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Russian folklore
artifacts.description: s (Cапоги-скороходы), allows the person wearing them to walk and run at an amazing pace. (Russian folklore)

artifacts.name: Seven-league boots
artifacts.description: a pair of boots said to allow the wearer to make strides of seven leagues in length. (European folklore)

artifacts.name: Sandals of Jesus Christ
artifacts.description: these were among the most important relics of the Catholic Church in the Middle Ages. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Talaria
artifacts.description: Hermes's winged sandals which allowed him to fly. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Helskór
artifacts.description: (Hel-shoes), were put on the dead so that they could go to Valhöll. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Víðarr
artifacts.description: of Víðarr, which gave the god Vidar unparalleled foot protection. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Babr-e Bayan
artifacts.description: the mythical coat worn by the Persian legendary hero Rostam in combat. (Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: The Coat of Padarn Red-Coat
artifacts.description: oat of Padarn Red-Coat: if a well-born man put it on, it would be the right size for him; if a churl, it would not go upon him. One of the Thirteen Treasures of the Island of Britain. (Welsh mythology)

artifacts.name: Freyja
artifacts.description: amr (Feather-skin), the goddess Freyja owns a cloak of falcon feathers. She assists other deities by allowing them to use her feathered cloak. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: swan
artifacts.description: Cloak, a magic robe made of swan feathers belonging to a swan maiden.

artifacts.name: Sigurd
artifacts.description: ppe, Sigurd's magical cloak that made the wearer invisible. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Thirteen Treasures of the Island of Britain
artifacts.description: rnyw), whoever was under it could not be seen, and he could see everyone. One of the Thirteen Treasures of the Island of Britain. This item is known from two other sources, the prose tales Culhwch and Olwen (c. 1100) and The Dream of Rhonabwy (early 13th century). A very similar mantle also appears in the Second Branch of the Mabinogi, in which it is used by Caswallawn to assassinate the seven stewards left behind by Bran the Blessed and usurp the throne. (Welsh mythology)

artifacts.name: Elijah
artifacts.description: of Elijah, the waters of which, touched by the Mantle (monastic vesture)mantle, divided, so as to permit both to pass over on dry ground across the Jordan River. (Abrahamic religion)

artifacts.name: Welsh mythology
artifacts.description: Gold-Breast, Tegau Gold-Breast (Tegau Eurfron, wife of Caradoc) was a Welsh heroine. Her mantle would not serve for any woman who had violated her marriage or her virginity. It would reach to the ground when worn by a faithful woman but would only hang down to the lap of an unfaithful wife. (Welsh mythology)

artifacts.name: Robe of the Fire-rat
artifacts.description: a legendary robe of China that is made of the fireproof fur of the fire-rat. One of Kaguya-hime's suitor set out to search for the robe. (Japanese mythology)

artifacts.name: Seamless Robe of Jesus
artifacts.description: (also Holy Robe, Holy Tunic, Honorable Robe or Chiton of the Lord), the robe said to have been worn by Jesus during or shortly before his crucifixion. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Sudarium of Oviedo
artifacts.description: and Veil of Veronica, purported "sweat cloths" that touched upon Jesus

artifacts.name: Woman of the Apocalypse
artifacts.description: the Apocalypse is clothed with the sun. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Nábrók
artifacts.description: (Death Underpants), a pair of pants made from the skin of a dead man, which are capable of producing an endless supply of money. (Icelandic folklore)

artifacts.name: Shirt of Nessus
artifacts.description: the poisoned shirt that killed Heracles. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Ragnar
artifacts.description: 's enchanted shirt, when King Ælla threw Ragnar into the snake pit, it was claimed Ragnar was protected by an enchanted shirt that Aslaug had made. It was only when this shirt had been removed that the snakes could bite Ragnar and kill him. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Cura Si Manjakini
artifacts.description: a sword mentioned in the legends of the Malay Annals as originally possessed by Sang Sapurba, the legendary ancestor of Malay kings. (Malay folklore)

artifacts.name: Flaming Sword
artifacts.description: a sword glowing with flame by some supernatural power.

artifacts.name: Grettir
artifacts.description: autr (Jokul's Gift), a sword belonging to Grettir which was later given to his brother Atli. (Sagas of Icelanders)

artifacts.name: Kaleva
artifacts.description: nmiekka, Kaleva's sword. (Finnish mythology)

artifacts.name: Sagas of Icelanders
artifacts.description: oom), Grettir defeats Kárr who was guarding the treasure in his own funeral tumulus from looters. The treasures are taken from the mound after Grettir's triumph, including an heirloom sword Kársnautr. (Sagas of Icelanders)

artifacts.name: Igbo mythology
artifacts.description: a sword that belongs to the Igbo god of war Kamalu. This sword glows red when people with evil intentions are close by and it can cause tremors when struck on the ground. It gifts mere mortals victory in battle. (Igbo mythology)

rd of Laban, after nearly being killed by a powerful and nefarious Laban, the young prophet Nephi later finds him drunk and unconscious. He's then commanded of God to use Laban's sword to kill him as he was wicked and would hurt future generations by withholding sacred records revealing God's Plan of Happiness. The sword was made of "precious steel" with a hilt of "pure gold".[2] After slaying Laban, Nephi put on Laban's armor to disguise himself to obtain the records, and escape the city. He would later use it as a model for manufacturing similar weapons for his people's defense. Laban's sword was passed down through the centuries to future prophets, kings, and warriors. (Book of Mormon)

artifacts.name: Sword of Victory
artifacts.description: (also Phra Saeng Khan Chaiyasi), the sword's history has been shrouded in myth and legend. In 1784, Chao Phraya Apai Pubet of Cambodia received the blade from a fisher who found in it in Tonle Sap when it was caught in his fishing net. He gave it to King Phutthayotfa Chulalok (Rama I) of Thailand, his suzerain at the time. According to legend, it was said that the moment the blade arrived in Bangkok, seven lightning strikes hit the city simultaneously, including the city gate, where the blade entered, and over the main gate of the Grand Palace. (Thai folklore)

artifacts.name: Thuận Thiên
artifacts.description: (Heaven's Will), the mythical sword of the Vietnamese King Lê Lợi, who liberated Vietnam from Ming occupation after ten years of fighting from 1418 until 1428. (Vietnamese mythology)

artifacts.name: Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse
artifacts.description: f the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse rides on a Red Horse is War, a great sword was given to him. (Book of Revelation)

artifacts.name: Goliath
artifacts.description: 's sword, which was used by David to decapitate the fallen giant, and then given to him by the priest Achimelech when he ran away from King Shaul. (Jewish mythology)

artifacts.name: Diarmuid Ua Duibhne
artifacts.description: egallta) or "Little Fierce One", a short sword given to Diarmuid Ua Duibhne by his father Aengus. It broke in two pieces after hitting a boar with it. Paired with Móralltach.

artifacts.name: Caladbolg
artifacts.description: (also Caladcholg), the sword of Fergus mac Róich and powerful enough to cut the tops off three hills; related to the Caledfwlch of Welsh mythology.

artifacts.name: Caledfwlch
artifacts.description: often compared to Excalibur. This sword is used by Llenlleawg Wyddel to kill Diwrnach Wyddel and his men.

artifacts.name: Oisín
artifacts.description: nan Gallan, the Smith of the Branches, sword of Oisín.

artifacts.name: Claíomh Solais
artifacts.description: (Sword of Light), the sword of Nuada Airgeadlámh. The sword glowed with the light of the sun and was irresistible in battle, having the power to cut his enemies in half.

artifacts.name: Oscar
artifacts.description: rach Mhor, the Great Triumphant One, sword of Oscar.

artifacts.name: Crocea Mors
artifacts.description: [fr], formerly the sword of Julius Caesar, captured by Nennius according to the legends presented by Geoffrey of Monmouth.

artifacts.name: Caílte mac Rónáin
artifacts.description: the Hard Destroying One, sword of Caílte mac Rónáin.

artifacts.name: Cú Chulainn
artifacts.description: tutchenn, the sword of Cú Chulainn.

artifacts.name: Rhydderch Hael
artifacts.description: Hilt), the Sword of Rhydderch Hael. When drawn by a worthy or well-born man, the entire blade would blaze with fire. Rhydderch was never reluctant to hand the weapon to anyone, hence his nickname Hael "the Generous", but the recipients, as soon as they had learned of its peculiar properties, always rejected the sword.

artifacts.name: Fragarach
artifacts.description: (also Sword of Air, Answerer or Retaliator), forged by the gods, wielded by Manannán mac Lir and Lugh Lamfada. No armor could stop it, and it would grant its wielder command over the powers of wind.

artifacts.name: Fionn mac Cumhaill
artifacts.description: on of the Waves, sword of Fionn mac Cumhaill.

artifacts.name: Diarmuid Ua Duibhne
artifacts.description: rallta) or "Great Fierce One", a sword given to Diarmuid Ua Duibhne by his father Aengus, which left no stroke or blow unfinished at the first trial.

artifacts.name: Tethra
artifacts.description: the sword of the Fomorian king Tethra, which recounts the deeds done with it when unsheathed. It was taken by Ogma and it then recounted everything it had done.

artifacts.name: Conaire Mór
artifacts.description: rd of Conaire Mór, a sword that would sing in battle.

artifacts.name: Torrent of Portyngale
artifacts.description: the sword of Torrent of Portyngale, according to the Torrent of Portyngale it was forged by Wayland the Smith.

artifacts.name: Gram
artifacts.description: the sword wielded by Sigurd/Siegfried. It is called Balmung in the Nibelungenlied and Nothung in Richard Wagner's Der Ring des Nibelungen.

artifacts.name: Háma
artifacts.description: gang (also Burtgang or Blodgang), the sword of Háma.

artifacts.name: Dietrich von Bern
artifacts.description: f Ecke), the sword that belonged to the giant Ecke before he was killed by Dietrich von Bern, who then took it for himself.

artifacts.name: Wudga
artifacts.description: g, a great sword that Wudga inherits from his father Wayland the Smith.

artifacts.name: Dietrich von Bern
artifacts.description: ord of Dietrich von Bern.

artifacts.name: Hereward the Wake
artifacts.description: word of Hereward the Wake.

artifacts.name: Hrunting
artifacts.description: the magical sword lent to Beowulf by Unferth which was annealed in venom.

artifacts.name: Nægling
artifacts.description: the other magical sword of Beowulf. Found in the cave of Grendel's mother.[3]

artifacts.name: Sword of Saint Peter
artifacts.description: St. Joseph of Arimathea brought the sword to Britain and it was kept at Glastonbury Abbey for many years until the Abbot gave it to Saint George. (English folklore)

artifacts.name: Wallace Sword
artifacts.description: William Wallace used human skin for his sword's scabbard, hilt, and belt. The flesh's donor was said to have been Hugh de Cressingham, treasurer of Scotland, whom Wallace had flayed after defeating him in the battle of Stirling Bridge. (Scottish folklore)

artifacts.name: Mordred
artifacts.description: a sword of peace meant for knighting and ceremonies as opposed to battle, which was stolen and then used to kill Arthur by Mordred.

artifacts.name: Coreiseuse (Wrathful), the sword of King Ban, Lancelot's father.
Excalibur
artifacts.description: it is also sometimes referred to as: Caliburn, Caledfwlch, Calesvol, Kaledvoulc'h, Caliburnus due to inconsistencies within the various Arthurian legends. Sometimes attributed with magical powers or associated with the rightful sovereignty of Great Britain. Stated that it was forged on the Isle of Avalon.

artifacts.name: Marmiadoise
artifacts.description: it is also known as Mamyadoise. Marmiadoise is a sword said to originally belong to the Greek deity Hercules and was later given to his descendants, this sword would eventually be used by King Rions until he was killed by King Arthur during a battle, this sword would later be adopted by Arthur himself as he considered it to be superior when compared to the Excalibur.

artifacts.name: Cortain
artifacts.description: (also Corte, Cortana, "Short"; Danish: Kortone), the shortened sword of Ogier the Dane, which was broken when test-cutting a marble block and had to be refashioned with the shorter blade.[4] And when Ogier was about to strike Prince Charlot dead in vengeance, but the archangel Michael stays the sword Short, and the prince is spared.[5] Ogier's sword had originally been the broken-tipped sword of Tristan according to the 13th century Prose Tristan. There appears to be some conflation between this sword from literature and the actual British regalia sword Curtana aka Sword of Mercy.

artifacts.name: Gawain
artifacts.description: ne, the name of the sword given to Sir Gawain by the Lady of the Lake.

artifacts.name: Percival
artifacts.description: ord, a cracked holy sword which Sir Percival bonded back together, though the crack remained.

artifacts.name: The Faerie Queene
artifacts.description: s sword crafted by Merlin in The Faerie Queene; "neither steele, nor stone" could fend its attack. (Renaissance fiction)

artifacts.name: Vulgate Cycle
artifacts.description: word that Lancelot used to battle the Saxons at Saxon Rock. It is translated as Seure (Sequence) in the Vulgate Cycle.

artifacts.name: Pellinore
artifacts.description: the Stone or Caliburn, a sword in the Arthurian legend which only the rightful king of Britain can pull from the stone; sometimes associated with Excalibur. In Mallory, the sword in the stone is not Excalibur and is not named. When the sword is broken in a fight with King Pellinore, the Lady of the Lake gives him Excalibur as a replacement. At Arthur's death, Excalibur is returned to the Lady of the lake by Sir Bedivere.

artifacts.name: Sir Balin
artifacts.description: h the Red Hilt, one of the swords wielded by Sir Balin. After his death, Merlin sealed it in the float stone where it remained until it was drawn by Sir Galahad. After Galahad, the sword passes to his father, Sir Lancelot who fatally wounds Sir Gawain with it.

artifacts.name: The Faerie Queene
artifacts.description: den sword of Sir Artegal in The Faerie Queene. It was tempered with Adamant, and it could cleave through anything. (Renaissance fiction)

artifacts.name: Greysteil
artifacts.description: a sword in the medieval poem Greysteil. Sir Graham obtains the sword 'Egeking' from Eger's aunt, Sir Egram's Lady.

artifacts.name: Guy of Warwick's Sword
artifacts.description: belonged to the legendary Guy of Warwick who is said to have lived in the 10th century.

artifacts.name: Beves
artifacts.description: lai, the king makes Beves a knight and presents him with a sword called Morgelai.

artifacts.name: Viking
artifacts.description: ðall (Stream of Anguish), a magical sword of Viking, and later Frithiof. It is inscribed with Runic letters which blaze in time of war but gleam with a dim light in time of peace.

artifacts.name: Dáinsleif
artifacts.description: (Dáinn's legacy), king Högni's sword that gave wounds that never healed and could not be sheathed without killing a man.

artifacts.name: Dragvandil
artifacts.description: [sv], the sword of Egill Skallagrímsson.

artifacts.name: Sword of Freyr
artifacts.description: the sword of the Norse god of summer Frey, it is a magic sword which fought on its own.

artifacts.name: Gram
artifacts.description: the sword that Odin struck into the world tree Barnstokkr which only Sigmund the Völsung was able to pull out. It broke in battle with Odin but was later reforged by Sigmund's son Sigurd who used it to slay the dragon Fafnir. After being reforged, it could cleave an anvil in half.

artifacts.name: Hǫfuð
artifacts.description: the sword of Heimdallr, the guardian of the Bifröst bridge.

artifacts.name: Hrotti
artifacts.description: part of Fafnir's treasure, which Sigurd took after he slew the dragon.

artifacts.name: Lævateinn
artifacts.description: a sword mentioned in an emendation to the Poetic Edda Fjölsvinnsmál by Sophus Bugge. it was forged by the elf Völundr.

artifacts.name: Legbiter
artifacts.description: the sword of Magnus III of Norway.

artifacts.name: Mistilteinn
artifacts.description: the magical sword of Thráinn, the draugr, later owned by Hromundr Gripsson and it could never go blunt.

artifacts.name: Haakon I of Norway
artifacts.description: of Haakon I of Norway and his follower, Thoralf Skolinson the Strong, said to be sharp enough to cut through quernstones.

artifacts.name: Ridill
artifacts.description: (also Refil), sword of the dwarf Regin.

artifacts.name: Skofnung
artifacts.description: the legendary sword of Danish king Hrólf Kraki. It was renowned for supernatural sharpness and hardness, as well as for being imbued with the spirits of the king's twelve faithful berserker bodyguards. A cut made by Skofnung will not heal. The only way to stop this is by touching the cut with the Skofnung stone.

artifacts.name: Surtr
artifacts.description: of Surtr the flaming sword of the fire giant king Surtr which he uses to slay Freyr and cover the realms in fire at the end of Ragnarök, possibly the same as Freyr's sword.

artifacts.name: Tyrfing
artifacts.description: (also Tirfing or Tyrving), the cursed sword of Svafrlami with a golden hilt that would never miss a stroke, would never rust and would cut through stone and iron as easily as through clothes. The dwarves made the sword, and it shone and gleamed like fire. However, they cursed it so that it would kill a man every time it was used and that it would be the cause of three great evils.

artifacts.name: Almace
artifacts.description: (also Almice or Almacia), sword of Turpin, Archbishop of Reims.

artifacts.name: Rogero
artifacts.description: rda, the sword of Rogero from Orlando Furioso made by a sorceress, and capable of cutting through enchanted substances.

artifacts.name: Durendal
artifacts.description: (also Durandal or Durlindana in Italian), the sword of Roland, one of Charlemagne's paladins, (Orlando in medieval Italian verse) — alleged to be the same sword as the one wielded by Hector of Ilium. It was said to be the sharpest sword in all of existence.

artifacts.name: Froberge
artifacts.description: the sword of Renaud de Montauban.

artifacts.name: Hauteclere
artifacts.description: (also Halteclere or Hauteclaire), the sword of Olivier. It is described as being of burnished steel, with a crystal embedded in a golden hilt.

artifacts.name: Joan of Arc
artifacts.description: 's sword, Joan's "voices" told her that a magical and holy sword would be found in the Church [fr] of Saint Catherine of Fierbois. It had five crosses upon it and that the rust was easily removed.

artifacts.name: Joyeuse
artifacts.description: sword of Charlemagne. Some legends claim Joyeuse was forged to contain the Lance of Longinus within its pommel; others say the blade was smithed from the same materials as Roland's Durendal and Ogier's Curtana.

artifacts.name: Doon de Mayence
artifacts.description: he hero's sword in Doon de Mayence. It was so sharp that when placed edge downwards it would cut through a slab of wood without the use of force.

artifacts.name: Murgleys
artifacts.description: (also Murgleis), sword of Ganelon, traitor and cousin of Roland. Its "gold pommel" held some kind of a "holy relic".

artifacts.name: Précieuse
artifacts.description: sword of Baligant, Emir of Babylon.

artifacts.name: Ogier the Dane
artifacts.description: ond of the two magical swords of Ogier the Dane.

artifacts.name: Colada
artifacts.description: the other sword of El Cid.[6]

artifacts.name: Lobera
artifacts.description: (Wolf Slayer), the sword of the king Saint Ferdinand III of Castile, inheritance of the epic hero Fernán González, according to Don Juan Manuel, Prince of Villena.[7]

artifacts.name: Tizona
artifacts.description: (also Tizón), the sword of El Cid, it frightens unworthy opponents, as shown in the heroic poem Cantar de Mio Cid.[8]

artifacts.name: Harpe
artifacts.description: an adamantine sword used by the hero Perseus to decapitate Medusa.

artifacts.name: Sword of Damocles
artifacts.description: a huge sword hung above the throne where Damocles sat, it was held at the pommel only by a single hair of a horse's tail.

artifacts.name: Sword of justice
artifacts.description: in Themis right hand, she is seen to have a sword that faces downward. This sword represents punishment.

artifacts.name: Peleus
artifacts.description: of Peleus, a magic sword that makes its wielder victorious in the battle or the hunt.

artifacts.name: Sword of Attila
artifacts.description: (also Sword of Mars or Sword of God), the legendary sword that was wielded by Attila the Hun; claimed to have originally been the sword of "Mars", the war god of the Scythic barbarians.[9]

artifacts.name: Aruval
artifacts.description: the Tamils revere the weapon, a type of billhook, as a symbol of Karupannar in (Tamil mythology)

artifacts.name: Asi
artifacts.description: a legendary sword mentioned in the epic Mahabharata.

artifacts.name: Chandrahasa
artifacts.description: the divine sword given to Ravana by Shiva

artifacts.name: Khanda
artifacts.description: (also Mahābhārata Sword), Khanda is represented as wisdom cutting through ignorance. In Hinduism, the Khanda is a symbol of Shiva. Khanda often appears in Rajput history but later on, it was used by Sikh warriors, scriptures, and art.

artifacts.name: Nandaka
artifacts.description: (also Nandaki), the sword of the Hindu god Vishnu.

artifacts.name: Pradyumna
artifacts.description: a, the sword of Pradyumna, a son of Krishna.

artifacts.name: Veerabhadra
artifacts.description: the divine sword of the Veerabhadra, a commander of Shiva's troops.

artifacts.name: Izanagi
artifacts.description: Ohabari (also Ama-no-Ohabari), used by Izanagi to kill his offspring, Kagu-tsuchi.

artifacts.name: Takemikazuchi
artifacts.description: ma (August-Snap-Spirit), the sword of Takemikazuchi.

artifacts.name: Juuchi Yosamu (10,000 Cold Nights), crafted by Muramasa – in a contest, Sengo Muramasa suspended the blade in a small creek with the cutting edge facing the current. Muramasa's sword cut everything that passed its way; fish, leaves floating down the river, the very air which blew on it.
Kogarasu Maru
artifacts.description: (Little Crow), a unique tachi sword believed to have been created by the legendary smith Amakuni during the 8th century CE.

artifacts.name: Inari Ōkami
artifacts.description: aru (Little Fox), Inari Ōkami and its fox spirits help the blacksmith Munechika forge the blade Kogitsune-maru at the end of the 10th century.

artifacts.name: Kusanagi-no-tsurugi
artifacts.description: (also Ama-no-Murakumo-no-Tsurugi and Tsumugari no Tachi), sword of the Japanese god Susanoo, later given to his sister Amaterasu.

artifacts.name: Totsuka-no-Tsurugi
artifacts.description: the sword Susanoo used to slay Yamata no Orochi.

artifacts.name: Yawarakai-Te (Tender Hands), crafted by Masamune – in a contest, Masamune Okazaki lowered his sword into the current and waited patiently. Only leaves were cut. However, the fish swam right up to it, and the air hissed as it gently blew by the blade. A monk who had been watching explained what he had seen; the Masamune was by far the finer of the two swords, as it did not needlessly cut that which is innocent and undeserving.
Lü Dongbin
artifacts.description: sword borrowed from Lü Dongbin to Xuanwu in order to subdue the spirits of the tortoise and the snake.

artifacts.name: Gan Jiang and Mo Ye
artifacts.description: the legendary Chinese twin swords named after their creators.

artifacts.name: Bön
artifacts.description: ry of Ten Powers, a legendary Chinese sword allegedly forged in Tibet by husband-and-wife magicians of the ancient Bön tradition.

artifacts.name: Zhuānxū
artifacts.description: a branch that morphed into a sword in the hands of Zhuānxū, has the ability to command the elements and animals.

artifacts.name: Huangdi
artifacts.description: an Sword, a sword given to Huangdi by Jiutian Xuannü during his war against Chiyou. Able to slay gods, demons and repel evil magic.

artifacts.name: Zhuānxū
artifacts.description: g, a sword that descended from heaven into the possession of Zhuānxū. Said to levitate and points towards the direction of war.

artifacts.name: Manjusri
artifacts.description: rasa, legendary sword of Manjusri, according to Swayambhu Purana used to found Kathmandu Valley, forms the centerpiece of flag of Kathmandu.

artifacts.name: Acala
artifacts.description: n, a metaphorical Buddhist sword used to cut away earthly desires, it is wielded by Acala.

artifacts.name: Khanda
artifacts.description: represents wisdom cutting through ignorance. Hindu and Buddhist deities are often shown welding or holding khanda sword in religious art. Notably, Buddhist guardian deities like Acala, Manjushri, Mahākāla and Palden Lhamo.

artifacts.name: Bolesław III Wrymouth
artifacts.description: sword of Bolesław III Wrymouth, medieval prince of Poland.

artifacts.name: Kladenets
artifacts.description: (also Samosek or Samosyok), the "self-swinging sword" is a fabulous magic sword in some Old Russian fairy tales. In English translations of Russian byliny and folklore, it may be rendered variously as "sword of steel". (Russian mythology)

artifacts.name: Szczerbiec
artifacts.description: (Notched Sword or Jagged Sword), a legend links Szczerbiec with Bolesław I the Brave who was said to have chipped the sword by hitting it against the Golden Gate, Kiev (now in Ukraine) during his intervention in the Kievan succession crisis in 1018.

artifacts.name: Shamshir-e Zomorrodnegar
artifacts.description: (Persian: شمشیر زمردنگار), "The emerald-studded Sword" in the Persian mythical story Amir Arsalan. The hideous horned demon called Fulad-zereh was invulnerable to all weapons except the blows of Shamshir-e Zomorrodnegar. This blade originally belonged to King Solomon. (Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Tahmuras
artifacts.description: ahmuras (Persian:تیغ تهمورث), "The Blade Of Tahmurath" is a heavenly blade made by the legendary Persian king Tahmurath in Iranian folk tales, which can neutralize magic and spells and destroy invulnerable creatures and demons. And it is usually used by Rostam and his family members. (Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Dhulfiqar
artifacts.description: a sword sent from the Heavens to the Islamic prophet Muhammad by the archangel Gabriel, which he was ordered to give to Ali ibn Abi Talib. (Islamic mythology)

artifacts.name: Heracles
artifacts.description: ' club, a gnarled olive-wood club wielded by Heracles. (Greek Mythology)

artifacts.name: Sharur
artifacts.description: the enchanted mace of the Sumerian god Ninurta. It can fly unaided and also may communicate with its wielder. (Mesopotamian mythology)

artifacts.name: Tishtrya
artifacts.description: 's mace, a mace wielded by Tishtrya that can create lightning and tornados. (Persian mythology)
e gāvsār, an ox-headed mace described in various Iranian and Zoroastrian myths that is used as a symbol of victory and justice.[10] (Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Mithra
artifacts.description: Mithra,A golden mace wielded by Mithras, the god of covenants, that can be thrown from a distance, he twirls his mace over the heads of the demons every day and night in Hell to prevent them from harming the spirits of the dead too much.(Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Kothar
artifacts.description: h and Ayamur, two clubs created by Kothar and used by Baal to defeat Yam. (Phoenician mythology)

artifacts.name: Indravarman III
artifacts.description: 's metalwood bat, a legendary bat wielded by a Cambodian emperor.[11] (Buddhist mythology)

artifacts.name: Dagda
artifacts.description: Mór, the magical club or staff of Dagda which was supposed to be able to kill nine men with one blow, but can return the slain to life with the handle. (Irish mythology)

artifacts.name: Kaumodaki
artifacts.description: the mace of the Hindu god Vishnu, found in iconography of some of Vishnu's avatars.
danda, the staff of Death[12] is a club used by Yama, the god of death in Hindu mythology. Once fired, it could kill anyone, no matter what boons they had to protect themselves.

artifacts.name: Gada
artifacts.description: the main weapon of the Hindu god Hanuman.

artifacts.name: Bhima
artifacts.description: of Bhima, a club that was presented by Mayasura. It was a weapon of the danava King Vrishaparva.

artifacts.name: Merlin
artifacts.description: 's staff, the staff of the legendary wizard of Camelot, advisor and mentor to king Arthur. (Arthurian legend)

artifacts.name: Prospero
artifacts.description: 's staff, staff belonging to the wizard Prospero in the Shakespearean play "The Tempest."

artifacts.name: Gambanteinn
artifacts.description: appears in two poems in the Poetic Edda. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Thor
artifacts.description: arvölr, a magical staff given to Thor by Gríðr so he could kill the giant Geirröd. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Nehushtan
artifacts.description: a staff of bronze made by Moses to erect so that the Israelites who saw it would be protected from dying from the bites of the "fiery serpents". (Jewish mythology)

artifacts.name: Rod of Asclepius
artifacts.description: a serpent-entwined rod wielded by Asclepius, a deity associated with healing and medicine. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Ruyi Jingu Bang
artifacts.description: the staff of Sun Wukong, which could alter its size from a tiny needle to a mighty pillar. (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Khaṭvāṅga
artifacts.description: Shiva and Rudra carried the khatvāṅga as a staff weapon and are thus referred to as khatvāṅgīs. In Buddhist mythology, it is a particularly divine attribute of Padmasambhava and endemic to his iconographic representation and depicted as an accoutrement of his divine consorts, Mandarava and Yeshe Tsogyal. In the twilight language, it represents Yab-Yum. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Aaron's rod
artifacts.description: was endowed with miraculous power during the Plagues of Egypt that preceded the Exodus. Was carried by Aaron. (Jewish mythology)

artifacts.name: Staff of Moses
artifacts.description: used by Moses to produce water from a rock, was transformed into a snake and back, and was used at the parting of the Red Sea. (Jewish mythology)

artifacts.name: Ruyi
artifacts.description: (As Desired or As [You] Wish), a curved decorative object that serves as a ceremonial sceptre in Chinese Buddhism or a talisman symbolizing power and good fortune in Chinese folklore. (Chinese folklore)

artifacts.name: Was
artifacts.description: (Power or Dominion), a scepter associated with the gods as well as with the pharaoh. In later use, it was a symbol of control over the force of chaos that Set represented. It appears as a stylized animal head at the top of a long, straight staff with a forked end. (Egyptian mythology)

artifacts.name: Circe
artifacts.description: 's staff, a staff with which the sorceress Circe could transform others into animals. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Thyrsus
artifacts.description: a staff tipped with a pine cone and entwined with ivy leaves, carried by Dionysus and his followers. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Caduceus
artifacts.description: (also Kerykeion), the staff carried by Hermes or Mercury. It is a short staff entwined by two serpents, sometimes surmounted by wings, and symbolic of commerce. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Cronus
artifacts.description: ' scythe, Cronus castrated his father Uranus using an adamant sickle given to him by his mother Gaia. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Grim Reaper
artifacts.description: 's scythe, a large scythe wielded by the Grim Reaper.

artifacts.name: Father Time
artifacts.description: ather Time, during the Renaissance, Father Time was depicted as wielding the harvesting scythe, and became the representative of the cruel and unrelenting flow of time which, in the end, cuts down all things.

artifacts.name: Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse
artifacts.description: he Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse rides on a Pale Horse is Death, he is commonly depict carrying a scythe. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Jangar
artifacts.description: the spear of Jangar. (Mongol mythology)

artifacts.name: St. George
artifacts.description: he spear (or sword) that St. George used to kill a dragon in Beirut and saving a princess from being sacrificed by the town. (Renaissance Fiction, Seven Champions of Christendom)

artifacts.name: Gungnir
artifacts.description: Odin's spear created by the Sons of Ivaldi. The spear is described as being so well balanced that it could strike any target, no matter the skill or strength of the wielder. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Atgeir
artifacts.description: 's Atgeir, Gunnar's atgeir would make a ringing sound or "sing" when it was taken down in anticipation of bloodshed. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Baligant
artifacts.description: the name of the spear of Baligant from The Song of Roland. (French folklore)

artifacts.name: Rhongomyniad
artifacts.description: (also Rhongomiant), the spear of King Arthur that he used to defeat the legendary Sir Thomas of Wolford. (Arthurian legend)

artifacts.name: Achilles
artifacts.description: Achilles, created by Hephaestus and given to Peleus at his wedding with Thetis. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Longinus
artifacts.description: Longinus, see Lances: Bleeding Lance and Holy Lance (below).

artifacts.name: Lugh
artifacts.description: dbhar (also Areadbhair), the spear of Lugh, which originally belonged to Pisear, king of Persia. Lugh had no need to wield the spear himself. It was alive and thirsted for blood that was only stayed by steeping its head in a sleeping-draught of pounded fresh poppy seeds. When battle was near, it was drawn out; then it roared and struggled against its thongs, fire blazed from it, and it tore through the ranks of the enemy once slipped from the leash, never tired of slaying.

artifacts.name: Manannán
artifacts.description: idhe, the spear of Manannán.

artifacts.name: Cú Chulainn
artifacts.description: Cú Chulainn's spear that first belonged to Nechtan Scéne, and used to kill the sons of Nechtan Scéne. Formerly the name for the charioteer's goad, a split piece of wood.

artifacts.name: Diarmuid Ua Duibhne
artifacts.description: haft), a yellow spear that can inflict wounds from which none could recover. The spear of Diarmuid Ua Duibhne, given to him by Aengus.

artifacts.name: Gáe Bulg
artifacts.description: the spear of Cú Chulainn, made of the bone of a sea monster. According to the legend, this spear was crafted by the warrior maiden Scáthach and had the power to explode into dozens of barbs, producing instant death.

artifacts.name: Gae Assail (Spear of Assal), another spear belonging to Lugh, the incantation "Ibar (Yew)" made the cast always hit its mark, and "Athibar (Re-Yew)" caused the spear to return.
Diarmuid Ua Duibhne
artifacts.description: lin), the red spear of Diarmuid Ua Duibhne, given to him by Aengus. It inflicted wounds that none could recover from similar to Gáe Buide.

artifacts.name: Lúin of Celtchar
artifacts.description: the name of a long, fiery lance or spear belonging to Celtchar mac Uthechar and wielded by other heroes, such as Dubthach, Mac Cécht and Fedlimid.

artifacts.name: Amenonuhoko
artifacts.description: (Heavenly Jewelled Spear), the naginata used by the Shinto deities Izanagi and Izanami to create the world – also called tonbogiri.

artifacts.name: Tenson kōrin
artifacts.description: hoko (Heavenly Upside Down Spear) is an antique and mysterious spear, staked by Ninigi-no-Mikoto at the summit of Takachiho-no-mine, where he and his divine followers first landed, according to the legend of Tenson kōrin.

artifacts.name: Nihongo, is one of three legendary Japanese spears created by the famed swordsmith Masazane Fujiwara. A famous spear that was once used in the Imperial Palace. Nihongo later found its way into the possession of Masanori Fukushima, and then Tahei Mori.
Otegine, is one of three legendary Japanese spears created by the famed swordsmith Masazane Fujiwara.
Tonbokiri
artifacts.description: is one of three legendary Japanese spears created by the famed swordsmith Masazane Fujiwara, said to be wielded by the legendary daimyō Honda Tadakatsu. The spear derives its name from the myth that a dragonfly landed on its blade and was instantly cut in two. Thus Tonbo (Japanese for "dragonfly") and kiri (Japanese for "cutting"), translating this spear's name as "Dragonfly Slaying spear".

artifacts.name: Erlang Shen
artifacts.description: 's spear, a three-pointed and double-edged spear with two cutting edges of a Saber used by Erlang Shen. It is powerful enough to penetrate and cleave through steel and stone like wool.

artifacts.name: Green Dragon Crescent Blade
artifacts.description: a legendary weapon wielded by Guan Yu in the historical novel Romance of the Three Kingdoms. It is a guandao, a type of traditional Chinese weapon. It is also sometimes referred to as the Frost Fair Blade, from the idea that during a battle in the snow, the blade continuously had blood on it; the blood froze and made a layer of frost on the blade.

artifacts.name: Zhu Bajie
artifacts.description: gpa (Nine-tooth Iron Rake), the primary weapon of Zhu Bajie.

artifacts.name: zhang
artifacts.description: hang long Serpent Spear, Zhang Fei's spear from the Three Kingdoms period in China.

artifacts.name: Spear of Fuchai
artifacts.description: the spear used by Goujian's arch-rival King Fuchai of Wu.

artifacts.name: Monk's spade
artifacts.description: rescent-Moon-Shovel), a Monk's spade that is the primary weapon of Sha Wujing. A double-headed staff with a crescent-moon blade at one end and a spade at the other, with six xīzhàng rings in the shovel part to denote its religious association.

artifacts.name: Han Feizi
artifacts.description: 's spear, a man was trying to sell a spear and a shield. When asked how good his spear was, he said that his spear could pierce any shield. Then, when asked how good his shield was, he said that it could defend from all spear attacks. Then one person asked him what would happen if he were to take his spear to strike his shield; the seller could not answer. This led to the idiom of "zìxīang máodùn" (自相矛盾, "from each-other spear shield"), or "self-contradictory".

artifacts.name: Bident
artifacts.description: a two-pronged implement resembling a pitchfork. In classical mythology, the bident is associated with Pluto/Hades, the ruler of the underworld. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: devil
artifacts.description: 's pitchfork, a bident or two-pronged pitchfork belonging to the devil. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Vel
artifacts.description: a divine javelin associated with Hindu war god Kartikeya. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Arthurian legend
artifacts.description: a sacred object, imbued with magic, in Grail ceremonies. Drops of blood issue from its point. When the Grail is Christianized, this weapon transforms into the Holy Lance, the spear that pierced the side of Jesus by the hand of a Roman soldier named Longinus. The blood is that of the lamb and drips eternally into the Grail. From the Vulgate Cycle on the Lance is also the weapon that inflicted the Grail-keeper's wound even though it is often attributed with healing powers. (Arthurian legend)

artifacts.name: Bradamante
artifacts.description: 's lance, a female Christian knight who wields a magical lance that unhorses anyone it touches. (Matter of France)

artifacts.name: Olyndicus
artifacts.description: Olyndicus, wielded by the Celtiberians' war chief Olyndicus, who fought against Rome. According to Florus, he wielded a silver lance that was sent to him by the gods from the sky.[13] (Spanish mythology)

artifacts.name: Holy Lance
artifacts.description: (also Spear of Longinus or Spear of Destiny), is the name given to the lance that pierced the side of Jesus as he hung on the cross, according to the Gospel of John. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Vajra
artifacts.description: A trident-shaped staff which emits a bright light in the darkness, and grants wisdom and insight. The staff belonged originally to the Japanese mountain god Kōya-no-Myōjin. It is the equivalent of the Sanskrit Vajra, the indestructible lightning-diamond pounder of the king of the gods/rain-god Indra. There the staff represents the three flames of the sacrificial fire, part of the image of the vajra wheel. (Japanese mythology)

artifacts.name: Trident of Poseidon
artifacts.description: associated with Poseidon, the god of the sea in Greek mythology and the Roman god Neptune. When struck the earth in anger, it caused mighty earthquakes and his trident could stir up tidal waves, tsunamis, and sea storms. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Lavanasura
artifacts.description: Madhu, Madhu handed everything over to his son Lavanasura including his trident before drowning himself in the ocean because of shame. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Trishula
artifacts.description: the trident of Shiva, stylized by some as used as a missile weapon and often included a crossed stabilizer to facilitate flight when thrown. Considered to be the most powerful weapon. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Chentu
artifacts.description: a horse whip which looks like a crooked stick, and is a typical attribute of Aiyanar, Krishna in his aspect as Rajagopala, and Shiva with Nandi. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Carnwennan
artifacts.description: (Little White-Hilt), the dagger of King Arthur. It is sometimes attributed with the power to shroud its user in shadow, and was used by Arthur to slice the Very Black Witch in half. (Arthurian legend)

artifacts.name: Rostam
artifacts.description: of Rostam, a glittering dagger that Rostam used to behead the white daeva Div-e Sepid. (Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Llawfrodedd Farchog
artifacts.description: d the Horseman, Llawfrodedd Farchog (from marchog "the Horseman"), or Barfawc "the Bearded" in other manuscripts, is said to have owned a knife which would serve for a company of 24 men at the dinner table. (Welsh mythology)

artifacts.name: Parazonium
artifacts.description: a dagger frequently carried by Virtus, Mars, Roma, or the Emperor, giving them the aura of courage. (Roman mythology)

artifacts.name: Kris Mpu Gandring
artifacts.description: Ken Arok's cursed dagger. The unfinished or incomplete kris would kill seven men, including Ken Arok.

artifacts.name: Kris Taming Sari
artifacts.description: (Flower Shield or Beautiful Shield), one of the most well-known kris in Malay literature, said to be so skilfully crafted that anyone wielding it was unbeatable.

artifacts.name: Kris Setan Kober
artifacts.description: belong to Arya Penangsang, the mighty viceroy (adipati) of Jipang who was killed by his own kris called Setan Kober ("devil of the grave"). Forged by Empu Bayu Aji in the kingdom of Pajajaran, and had 13 luk on its blade.

artifacts.name: Axe of Perun
artifacts.description: the axe wielded by the Slavic god of thunder and lightning, Perun. (Slavic paganism)

artifacts.name: Forseti
artifacts.description: 's axe (also Fosite's axe), a golden battle axe that Forseti (or Fosite in the Frisian mythology) used to save the old sages of the wreck and then threw the axe to an island to bring forth a source of water. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Hephaestus
artifacts.description: 's Labrys, a double-headed axe used by Hephaestus to slice open Zeus's head and free Athena, whose pregnant mother Zeus swallowed to prevent her offspring from dethroning him. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Maya
artifacts.description: tning axe, an axe that is wielded by the Maya rain deity Chaac and used to produce thunder and rain. (Maya mythology)

artifacts.name: Parashu
artifacts.description: the battle-axe of Shiva who gave it to Parashurama. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Pangu
artifacts.description: 's axe, an axe wielded by Pangu. He used it to separate yin from yang, creating the Earth (murky yin) and the Sky (clear yang). (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Paul Bunyan
artifacts.description: 's axe, an axe wielded by Paul Bunyan. It was responsible for carving the Grand Canyon after Paul once dragged it behind him while walking. (American folklore)

artifacts.name: Gobán Saor
artifacts.description: 's axe, it could hold back the tide when it was thrown onto the seashore. (Irish mythology)

artifacts.name: Shango
artifacts.description: 's axe, an axe wielded by Shango that can produce thunder. (Yoruba mythology)

artifacts.name: Zeus
artifacts.description: 's Labrys, at Labraunda there were depictions of Zeus who was called Zeus Labrandeus (Ζεὺς Λαβρανδεύς) with a tall lotus-tipped sceptre upright in his left hand and the double-headed axe over his right shoulder. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: woodcutter
artifacts.description: a woodcutter accidentally dropped his axe into a river and sat down to weep. Hermes dived into the water and returned with a golden axe. Hermes asked if this is his axe, but the woodcutter said it was not. (Greek folklore)

artifacts.name: woodcutter
artifacts.description: the woodcutter returned the same answer when a silver axe was brought to the surface by Hermes. Only when his own axe is found does he claim it. Impressed by his honesty, Hermes allows him to keep all three axes. (Greek folklore)

artifacts.name: Mjölnir
artifacts.description: a magical hammer wielded by Thor. It was invulnerable and when thrown would return to the user's hand. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Ukonvasara
artifacts.description: (also Ukonkirves), the weapon of the Finnish thunder god Ukko. (Finnish mythology)

artifacts.name: Uchide no kozuchi
artifacts.description: a legendary Japanese "magic hammer" which can "tap out" anything wished for, and is wielded by Daikoku-ten in popular belief. (Japanese folklore)

artifacts.name: Hephaestus
artifacts.description: Hephaestus, the hammer of the Greek god Hephaestus, which he used to make the Greek gods' weapons. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Arash
artifacts.description: 's bow, Arash used the bow to determine the border between Persia and Turan, it is said that the arrow was traveling for three days, and Arash sacrificed himself while firing the bow by putting his life force in the arrow. (Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Tristan
artifacts.description: t, the bow of Tristan. It was said to never miss its mark. (Arthurian legend)

artifacts.name: Houyi
artifacts.description: 's bow, the God of Archery used his bow to shoot down nine out of ten sun-birds from the sky. (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse
artifacts.description: e Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse rides on a White Horse is Conquest, and he who sat on it had a bow. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Ofas, bows and arrows used by the divine odés (hunters). (Yoruba mythology)
Kērēsāspa
artifacts.description: 's bow, The bow with which Kērēsāspa went to war with the giant demonic bird Kamak and shot infinite arrows like rain into its wings and brought it down and killed it. People also know that bow as a rainbow in the sky.(Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Apollo
artifacts.description: 's bow, a silver bow wielded by Apollo, used to slay Python.

artifacts.name: Artemis
artifacts.description: 's bow, a silver bow wielded by Artemis.

artifacts.name: Eros
artifacts.description: 's bow, a bow wielded by Eros that could cause one to love or hate the person they first saw after being struck.

artifacts.name: Heracles
artifacts.description: 's bow, which also belonged to Philoctetes, its arrows had been dipped in the blood of the Lernaean Hydra, which made them instantly lethal.

artifacts.name: Eurytus
artifacts.description: ' bow, Eurytus became so proud of his archery skills that he challenged Apollo. The god killed Eurytus for his presumption, and Eurytus' bow was passed to Iphitus, who later gave the bow to his friend Odysseus. It was this bow that Odysseus used to kill the suitors who had wanted to take his wife, Penelope.

artifacts.name: Pinaka
artifacts.description: a bow wielded by Shiva that fired arrows that could not be intercepted.

artifacts.name: Vijaya
artifacts.description: a bow wielded by Parashurama.

artifacts.name: Gandiva
artifacts.description: a bow created by Brahma and used by Arjuna during the Kurukshetra War.

artifacts.name: Sharanga
artifacts.description: the bow of the Hindu god Vishnu and his avatars.

artifacts.name: Kaundinya
artifacts.description: 's bow, a magic bow wielded by the Brahman Kaundinya, who used it to make the Naga princess Mera fall in love with him.[14]

artifacts.name: Indra
artifacts.description: 's bow, the rainbow is depicted as an archer's bow. Indra, the god of thunder and war, uses the rainbow to shoot arrows of lightning.

artifacts.name: Apollo
artifacts.description: 's arrow, An arrow that could cause health or cause famine and death in sleep. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Artemis
artifacts.description: 's arrow, golden arrows that could be used to bring sudden death and disease to girls and women. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Arrow of Brahma
artifacts.description: the demi-god Rama faced the demon king of Sri-Lanka, Ravana. Rama fired the arrow of Brahma that had been imparted to him by Agastya. The arrow of Brahma burst Ravana's navel, and returned to Rama's quiver. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Shiva
artifacts.description: Baan, Shiva gave Barbarika three infallible arrows (Teen Baan). A single arrow was enough to destroy all opponents in any war, and it would then return to Barbarika's quiver. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Elf-arrow
artifacts.description: (also Pixie Arrow), were arrowheads of flint used in hunting and war by the aborigines of the British Isles and of Europe in general. Elf-Arrows derived their name from the folklore belief that the arrows fell from the sky, and were used by elves to kill cattle and inflict Elfshot on human beings. Elf-Arrows were sometimes worn as amulets, occasionally set in silver, as a charm against witchcraft. (English folklore)

artifacts.name: Heracles
artifacts.description: ' arrows, arrows wielded by Heracles that were coated in poisonous Hydra blood. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Örvar-Oddr
artifacts.description: r, magic arrows given to Örvar-Oddr by his father. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Sagitta
artifacts.description: (Arrow), regarded as the weapon that Hercules used to kill the eagle Aquila that perpetually gnawed Prometheus' liver. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Kim Quy
artifacts.description: Crossbow of the Supernaturally Luminous Golden Claw (also 靈光金爪神弩; SV: Linh Quang Kim Trảo Thần Nỏ), which could kill 300 men with one shot. A giant golden turtle (also Kim Quy) gave An Dương Vương one of his claws and instructed him to make a crossbow using it as a trigger, assuring him he would be invincible with it.[‡ 1][15] A man called Cao Lỗ (or Cao Thông) was tasked with the creation of the crossbow.[‡ 1][16]: 88 [17](see also Vietnamese mythology)

artifacts.name: William Tell
artifacts.description: 's crossbow: the governor of Altdorf forced William to shoot with his crossbow at an apple placed over his son's head a hundred feet away, as a way of punishing him for not bowing to the governor's statue. William, despite being a master of the crossbow, loaded two arrows into it. At the first attempt he hit the target. Amazed, the governor asked the reason for loading the second arrow. William replied that, in case the first projectile hit his son, he would shoot the second arrow into the evil heart of the one who caused his death. (Swiss folklore)

artifacts.name: Lugh
artifacts.description: g-stone (also Cloich Tabaill), was used by Lugh to slay his grandfather, Balor the Strong-Smiter in the Cath Maige Tuired according to the brief accounts in the Lebor Gabála Érenn. (Irish mythology)

artifacts.name: Thunderbolt
artifacts.description: lightning plays a role in many mythologies, often as the weapon of a sky god and weather god. Thunderbolts as divine weapons can be found in many mythologies. In Greek mythology, the thunderbolt is a weapon given to Zeus by the Cyclops, or by Hephaestus in Greek mythology. Zibelthiurdos of Paleo-Balkan mythology is a god recognized as similar to Zeus as a wielder of lightning and thunderbolts. In Igbo mythology, the thunderbolt is the weapon of Amadioha and in Yoruba mythology, the thunderbolt is the weapon of Shango.

artifacts.name: Xiuhcoatl
artifacts.description: a lightning-like weapon wielded by Huitzilopochtli. (Aztec religion)

artifacts.name: Loki
artifacts.description: y Dart or Mistletoe, a weapon that Loki used to kill Baldr, variously depicted as a holly dart, mistletoe, arrow, or spear. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Lugh
artifacts.description: lum, the missile fired by Lugh from the Sling-stone. (Irish mythology)

artifacts.name: devil
artifacts.description: Bullet, an enchanted bullet obtained through a contract with the devil in the German folk legend Freischütz. A marksman has obtained a certain number of bullets destined to hit without fail whatever object he wishes. Six of the magic bullets are thus subservient to the marksman's will, but the seventh is at the absolute disposal of the devil himself. (German folklore)

artifacts.name: Silver bullet
artifacts.description: a bullet cast from silver that is often the only weapon effective against a werewolf, witch, or other monsters.

artifacts.name: Nezha
artifacts.description: nken, a chakram of great power wielded by Nezha. (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Astra
artifacts.description: a supernatural weapon, presided over by a specific deity. To summon or use an astra required knowledge of a specific incantation/invocation, when armed.

artifacts.name: Brahmastra
artifacts.description: described in a number of the Puranas, it was considered the deadliest weapon. It was said that when the Brahmastra was discharged, there was neither a counterattack nor a defense that could stop it.

artifacts.name: Narayanastra
artifacts.description: the personal missile of Vishnu in his Narayana or Naraina form.

artifacts.name: Pashupatastra
artifacts.description: an irresistible and most destructive personal weapon of Shiva and Kali, discharged by the mind, the eyes, words, or a bow.

artifacts.name: Varunastra
artifacts.description: a water weapon (a storm) according to the Indian scriptures, incepted by Varuna. In stories it is said to assume any weapon's shape, just like water. This weapon is commonly mentioned as being used to counter the Agneyastra.

artifacts.name: Agni
artifacts.description: yastra, the god of fire Agni possess a weapon that would discharge and emit flames inextinguishable through normal means.

artifacts.name: Sudarshana Chakra
artifacts.description: a legendary spinning disc like weapon used by the Hindu God Vishnu.

artifacts.name: Vajra
artifacts.description: the weapon of the Vedic rain and thunder-deity Indra, and is used symbolically by the dharmic traditions to represent firmness of spirit and spiritual power. (Hindu mythology/Buddhist mythology/Jain mythology)

artifacts.name: Brahmanda Astra
artifacts.description: it is said in the epic Mahabharata that the weapon manifests with the all five heads of Lord Brahma as its tip. Brahma earlier lost his fifth head when he fought with Lord Shiva. This weapon is said to possess the power to destroy entire solar system or Brahmand, the 14 realms according to Hindu cosmology.

artifacts.name: Brahmashirsha Astra
artifacts.description: It is thought that the Brahmashirsha Astra is the evolution of the Brahmastra, and 4 times stronger than Brahmastra. The weapon manifests with the four heads of Lord Brahma as its tip. When it strikes an area it will cause complete destruction and nothing will grow, not even a blade of grass, for the next 12 years. It will not rain for 12 years in that area, and everything including metal and earth become poisoned.

artifacts.name: Indra
artifacts.description: i Shakti, the magical dart of Indra. Used by Karna against Ghatotkacha in the Mahabharata war.

artifacts.name: Brísingamen
artifacts.description: the necklace of the goddess Freyja. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Necklace of Harmonia
artifacts.description: allowed any woman wearing it to remain eternally young and beautiful, but also brought great misfortune to all of its wearers or owners. It was made by Hephaestus and given to Harmonia, the daughter of Aphrodite and Ares, as a curse on the House of Thebes for Aphrodite's infidelity. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Lady of the Lake
artifacts.description: Lady of the Lake, a jeweled necklace given to Sir Pelleas after assisting an old woman across a river. It was enchanted so that its wearer would be unfathomably loved. (Arthurian legend)

artifacts.name: Yasakani no Magatama
artifacts.description: a bejeweled necklace of magatamas offered to Amaterasu. One of three Sacred Imperial Relics of Japan. It represents benevolence. (Japanese mythology)

artifacts.name: Izanagi
artifacts.description: ana-no-kami, a necklace of beads. Izanagi gave Amaterasu as a representation of her rule over Takama-ga-hara. (Japanese mythology)

artifacts.name: Agimat
artifacts.description: a Filipino word for "amulet" or "charm".

artifacts.name: Ankh
artifacts.description: an amulet which appears frequently in Egyptian tomb paintings and other art, often at the fingertips of a god or goddess. (Egyptian mythology)

artifacts.name: Phylactery, an amulet or charm, worn for its supposed magical power.
Rabbit's foot
artifacts.description: the foot of a rabbit is carried as an amulet believed to bring good luck. (American folklore/Canadian folklore)

artifacts.name: Vedic amulet
artifacts.description: in Vedic literature, fig trees often represent talismans with the udumbara fig tree having been deemed the "lord of amulets". (Hindu mythology/Buddhist mythology)

artifacts.name: Wolfssegen
artifacts.description: (also Wolfsegen and Wolf-Segen), an apotropaic charm against wolves. (European folklore)

artifacts.name: Andvaranaut
artifacts.description: a magical ring capable of producing gold, first owned by Andvari. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Draupnir
artifacts.description: a golden arm ring possessed by Odin that is a source of endless wealth. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Sir Lancelot
artifacts.description: el, a ring given to Sir Lancelot by the Lady of the Lake which could dispel any enchantment. In Le Chevalier de la Charrette it is given to him by a fairy instead. He used the ring to cross the Sword Bridge. (Arthurian legend)

artifacts.name: Cantar de los Siete Infantes de Lara
artifacts.description: lo Gustioz breaks in two pieces to so he can later on recognize the son with which his lover is pregnant. When that son, Mudarra, joins the two halves, it again becomes a complete ring and Gonzalo Gustioz is healed of his blindness in the epic poem Cantar de los Siete Infantes de Lara.[18] (Spanish mythology)

artifacts.name: Ring of Gyges
artifacts.description: a mythical magical artifact that granted its owner the power of invisibility. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Seal of Solomon
artifacts.description: a magical brass or steel ring that could imprison demons. (Jewish mythology/Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Svíagriss
artifacts.description: Adils' prized ring in the Hrólfr Kraki's saga. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Welsh mythology
artifacts.description: of Eluned the Fortunate, a cloak of invisibility owned by Merlin. (Welsh mythology)

artifacts.name: Angelica
artifacts.description: 's ring, a ring possessed by Angelica, princess of Cathay in the legends of Charlemagne. It rendered its wearer immune to all enchantments, and renders the user invisible when placed in their mouth. (Mythology in France)

artifacts.name: Alberich
artifacts.description: en ring, Alberich steals the Rhinegold from the Rhinemaidens, having learned that he who is willing to renounce love will thereby gain the ability to forge a ring of power from the gold. Alberich forges the ring and makes himself lord over all the Nibelungen. (German mythology)

artifacts.name: Aladdin
artifacts.description: 's ring, a magic ring the sorcerer from the Maghreb has lent him. When he rubs his hands in despair, he inadvertently rubs the ring and a genie appears. (Arabic mythology)

artifacts.name: Soria Moria Castle
artifacts.description: rincesses gave Halvor a ring to wish himself to his parents and back to Soria Moria Castle. (Scandinavian folklore)

artifacts.name: Krishna
artifacts.description: a golden jewellery, worn by Krishna on his arm over the biceps. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Karna
artifacts.description: Kundala, the ear-rings of Karna (was present at his birth). (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Shiva
artifacts.description: akundala, makara shaped ear-rings are sometimes worn by the Hindu gods, for example Shiva, the Destroyer, or the Preserver-god Vishnu, the Sun god Surya, and the Mother Goddess Chandi. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Shiva
artifacts.description: Kundala, the Hindu God Shiva wears two earrings or Kundalas. Traditional images of Shiva depict the two earrings named – Alakshya and Niranjana. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Lyngurium
artifacts.description: (also Ligurium), the name of a mythical gemstone believed to be formed of the solidified urine of the lynx. (Medieval legend)

artifacts.name: Batrachite
artifacts.description: gemstones that were supposedly found in frogs, to which ancient physicians and naturalists attributed the virtue of resisting poison. (Medieval legend)

artifacts.name: Draconite, a mythical gemstone taken from the head of a dragon and believed to have magical properties.
Tide jewels
artifacts.description: the kanju (干珠?, lit. "(tide-)ebbing jewel") and manju (満珠?, lit. "(tide-)flowing jewel") were magical gems that the Sea God used to control the tides. (Japanese mythology)

artifacts.name: Mermaid
artifacts.description: tears, Neptune forbade the mermaids to use their abilities to change the course of nature. In a horrible storm, one mermaid weathered the crossings for a ship. She had, over time, grown to fall in love with the ship's captain from afar. When she calmed the wind and waves to save the man's life, Neptune angrily exiled her to the depths of the ocean, and ordered her to never to swim to the surface again. Still, today, her brightly gleaming tears wash up on the shore as sea glass as a reminder of true love. (Medieval legend)

artifacts.name: Japanese mythology
artifacts.description: from a Dragon's Neck, a jewel that shines five colors found in a dragon's neck. One of Kaguya-hime's suitor set out to search for the jewel. (Japanese mythology)

artifacts.name: Hope Diamond
artifacts.description: the diamond has been surrounded by a mythology of a reputed curse to the effect that it brings misfortune and tragedy to persons who own it or wear it, but there are strong indications that such stories were fabricated to enhance the stone's mystery and appeal, since increased publicity usually raised the gem's value and newsworthiness. Unsubstantiated legends claim that the original form of the Hope Diamond was stolen from an eye of a sculpted statue of the goddess Sita, the wife of Rama, the seventh Avatar of Vishnu.

artifacts.name: oriental dragons
artifacts.description: lso Wish-granting pearl), oriental dragons are shown with a flaming pearl under their chin or in their claws. The pearl is associated with spiritual energy, wisdom, prosperity, power, immortality, thunder, or the moon. (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Kukulkan
artifacts.description: ukulkan, the Mayan god brought fire, earth, air, and water to the world. Kukulkan, though, only has the wind gem, and with it can control the air. (Maya mythology) [citation needed]

artifacts.name: Cintamani
artifacts.description: (also Chintamani Stone), a wish-fulfilling jewel within both Hindu and Buddhist traditions, equivalent to the philosopher's stone in Western alchemy. (Hindu mythology/Buddhist mythology)

artifacts.name: Kaustubha
artifacts.description: is a divine jewel or "Mani", which is in the possession of Vishnu. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Navaratna
artifacts.description: are the sacred nine "royal gems". (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Syamantaka
artifacts.description: (also Syamantakamani and Shyamantaka Jewel), the most famous jewel that is supposed to be blessed with magical powers. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Atet
artifacts.description: (also Sun Barge of Ra), the legendary boat that the Egyptian Solar deity Ra used to cross the sky during the day, and which bore his body through the Twelve Kingdoms of Knight. (Egyptian mythology)

artifacts.name: mortar and pestle
artifacts.description: pestle of Baba Yaga, she flies around in a mortar and using the pestle as a rudder. (Slavic Mythology)

artifacts.name: Magic carpet
artifacts.description: (also Flying carpet), a legendary carpet that can be used to transport humans who are on it instantaneously or quickly to their destination. (Arabian mythology)

artifacts.name: Flying Throne of Kai Kavus
artifacts.description: an eagle-propelled craft built by the Persian king Kay Kāvus. It was used for flying the king all the way to China. (Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Jamshid
artifacts.description: 's flying throne, a golden throne that Jamshid built and ordered the demons to lift it from Babylon to Azerbaijan. According to the Shahnameh, people named that day Nowruz to commemorate this event.(Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Mug Ruith
artifacts.description: ch (lit. Rowing Wheel), the magical flying machine of Mug Ruith, a mythological Irish Druid who along with his feathered headdress (the encennach), hovers across the skies [2]. (Irish Mythology)

artifacts.name: Chasse-galerie
