artifacts.description: (also Bewitched Canoe or Flying Canoe), Baptiste had a canoe with paddles, he made a pact with the devil so his canoe would fly wherever Baptiste wished. However, those within the canoe could not say the name of God, fly over a church, touch any crosses, or the canoe would crash. Baptiste uttered the magic words: "Acabris! Acabras! Acabram" to make the canoe fly. (Canadian folklore)

artifacts.name: Santa Claus
artifacts.description: igh, Santa Claus on a reindeer sleigh pulled by flying reindeer and help him deliver presents to children. (Modern folklore)

artifacts.name: besom
artifacts.description: 's broom, European witches are usually depicted flying on broomsticks, known as a besom. (Medieval legend)

artifacts.name: Lagâri Hasan Çelebi
artifacts.description: 's rocket, Lagari Hasan Çelebi made a successful crewed rocket flight, launched in a 7-winged rocket using 50 okka (140 lbs) of gunpowder from Sarayburnu, the point below Topkapı Palace in Istanbul. (Ottoman legend)

artifacts.name: Nezha
artifacts.description: 's wind and fire wheels, the Immortal Taiyi gave Nezha a wind-wheel and a fire-wheel. These were stood on whilst chanting incantations, to serve as a magic vehicle in the mythological story Fengshen Yanyi. (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Pushpa Vimana
artifacts.description: (An Aeroplane with flowers), a mythical Aeroplane found in Ayyavazhi mythology. In Maharashtra, it is the Pushpak Viman (a heavenly aircraft shaped as an eagle) which took Saint Tukaram (a devotee of Vishnu) to heaven.

artifacts.name: Pushpaka Vimana
artifacts.description: or Dandu Monara – Pushpaka was originally made by Vishvakarma for Brahma, the Hindu god of creation; later Brahma gave it to Kubera, the god of wealth; but it was later stolen, along with Lanka, by his half-brother, the king Ravana.

artifacts.name: Morgan Mwynfawr
artifacts.description: an Mwynfawr, a chariot belonging to Morgan Mwynfawr which would quickly reach whatever destination one might wish to go to. (Welsh mythology)

artifacts.name: Flidais
artifacts.description: 's chariot, a chariot drawn by deer. (Irish mythology)

artifacts.name: Hebo
artifacts.description: 's chariot, a chariot pulled by two dragons. (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Ukko
artifacts.description: 's chariot, cause thunderstorms when Ukko drove his chariot through the skies. (Finnish mythology)

artifacts.name: Merkabah
artifacts.description: (chariot), Ezekiel's vision of the four-wheeled chariot driven by four hayyot, each of which has four wings and the four faces of a man, lion, ox, and eagle.

artifacts.name: Chariot of fire
artifacts.description: the chariot that carried the prophet Elijah to heaven.

artifacts.name: Aphrodite
artifacts.description: 's chariot, Hephaestus presented Aphrodite with a golden chariot as bridal gift.

artifacts.name: Apollo
artifacts.description: 's chariot, was pulled by his sacred swans. He also gave his lover Hyacinthus a swan-drawn chariot.

artifacts.name: Ares
artifacts.description: 's chariots, Ares received his chariots from the forge of Hephaestus, they were pulled by immortal horses.

artifacts.name: Artemis
artifacts.description: 's chariot, it was made of gold and was pulled by the four golden-horned deer she caught. The bridles of her chariot were also made of gold.

artifacts.name: Cabeiri
artifacts.description: 's chariot, drawn by metallic, fire-breathing horses.

artifacts.name: Dionysus
artifacts.description: 's chariot, drawn by panthers.

artifacts.name: Eos
artifacts.description: 's chariot, drawn by two horses.

artifacts.name: Hades
artifacts.description: 's chariot, golden chariot drawn by four black horses.

artifacts.name: Helios
artifacts.description: 's chariot, a golden chariot drawn by four fiery horses driven across the sky by the Greek sun god, Helios. Also, according to Apollodorus, Helios owened a chariot, drawn by winged dragons, which he gave to his granddaughter Medea.[19]

artifacts.name: Hera
artifacts.description: 's chariot, a chariot drawn by peacocks.

artifacts.name: Nemesis
artifacts.description: 's chariot, a chariot drawn by griffins.

artifacts.name: Poseidon
artifacts.description: 's chariot, pulled by hippocampi.

artifacts.name: Rhea
artifacts.description: 's chariot, drawn by lions.

artifacts.name: Selene
artifacts.description: 's chariot, drawn across the night sky by her bulls or horses.

artifacts.name: Sol Invictus
artifacts.description: 's chariot, depicted riding a quadriga on the reverse of a Roman coin.

artifacts.name: Zeus
artifacts.description: 's chariot, drawn by the four directional winds (Anemoi) in horse-shape.

artifacts.name: Rahu
artifacts.description: 's chariot, drawn by eight black horses. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Surya
artifacts.description: 's chariot, drawn by seven horses. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Vitthakalai
artifacts.description: a gold-decorated chariot of Kali. (Ayyavazhi mythology)

artifacts.name: Thor
artifacts.description: 's chariot, driven across the sky by Thor and pulled by his two goats Tanngrisnir and Tanngnjóstr.

artifacts.name: Freyja
artifacts.description: 's chariot, a chariot pulled by cats.

artifacts.name: Álfröðull
artifacts.description: (Elf-beam, Elf-disc or Elf-glory, Elf-heaven), referring both to the sun-chariot of the sun goddess Sól and to the rider Sól. Álfröðull is pulled by two horses, Árvakr and Alsviðr across the sky each day.

artifacts.name: Caleuche
artifacts.description: a mythical ghost ship of the Chilote mythology and local folklore of the Chiloé Island, in Chile. (Chilote mythology)

artifacts.name: Gluskab
artifacts.description: f Gluskab, able to expand so it could hold an army, or shrink to fit in the palm of your hand. (Abenaki mythology)

artifacts.name: Māui
artifacts.description: e of Māui, it became the South Island of New Zealand. (Māori mythology)

artifacts.name: Guingelot
artifacts.description: Thomas Speght, an editor or Chaucer's works at the end of the 16th century, made a passing remark "Concerning Wade and his bote called Guingelot", and also his strange exploits in the same.

artifacts.name: The Preserver of Life
artifacts.description: the ship built in the Epic of Gilgamesh by Utnapishtim and the craftspeople of his village at the request of Enki Ea to hold his wife and relatives, as well as the village craftspeople, the animals to be saved, and various grains and seeds. (Mesopotamian mythology)

artifacts.name: Lugh
artifacts.description: Sweeper, a magic boat belonging to Lugh. (Irish mythology)

artifacts.name: Flying Dutchman
artifacts.description: a legendary ghost ship that can never make port and is doomed to sail the oceans forever. (Nautical folklore)

artifacts.name: giants
artifacts.description: fual, the ship of the giants. (North-Frisian mythology)

artifacts.name: Prydwen
artifacts.description: (also Pridwen), the ship of King Arthur, according to the Welsh poem, The Spoils of Annwfn. This ship also appeared in Culhwch and Olwen, when Arthur traveled to Ireland, to fetch the cauldron of Diwrnach and the boar Twrch Trwyth. In later Arthurian legend, Pridwen was the name of Arthur's shield. (Arthurian legend)

artifacts.name: Noah's Ark
artifacts.description: the vessel by which God spares Noah, his family, and a remnant of all the world's animals from the flood. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Chinese treasure ship
artifacts.description: (also Baochuan), a large wooden ship in the fleet of admiral Zheng He, who led seven voyages during the early 15th-century Ming dynasty. (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Takarabune
artifacts.description: (Treasure Ship), a mythical ship piloted through the heavens by the Seven Lucky Gods during the first three days of the New Year. (Japanese folklore)

artifacts.name: Mendam Berahi
artifacts.description: a legendary flagship of Malacca Sultanate. (Malay folklore)

artifacts.name: Ghost Ship of Northumberland Strait
artifacts.description: a ghost ship said to sail ablaze within the Northumberland Strait. (Canadian folklore)

artifacts.name: Mahogany Ship
artifacts.description: a putative early Australian shipwreck that is believed by some to lie beneath the sand in the Armstrong Bay area, approximately 3 to 6 kilometres west of Warrnambool in southwest Victoria, Australia. (Australian folklore)

artifacts.name: Lohengrin
artifacts.description: 's boat, a swan-drawn boat. (Medieval legend)

artifacts.name: Estonian mythology
artifacts.description: alled the valge laev, is mythical ship that brings freedom or takes people away to a better land. (Estonian mythology)

artifacts.name: Atet
artifacts.description: the solar barge of the sun god Ra. It was also known as the Mandjet (Egyptian for "The Boat of Millions of Years") and, during the night, as the Mesektet.

artifacts.name: Matet
artifacts.description: (Growing Stronger), the first of two boats traveled in by Ra, the sun god as he traveled the sky daily with the sun on his head. During the period between dawn and noon, Ra occupies the Matet boat.

artifacts.name: Seqtet
artifacts.description: (Growing Weaker), the second six hours of the day (from noon till dusk) in Ancient Egyptian belief. It was preceded by the Matet boat. The Seqtet boat is represented by the Sun as Ra, and Ra as a boat since it sails across the sky like a boat on water.

artifacts.name: Neshmet
artifacts.description: a vessel belonging to the god Nun. Osiris was transported in it on the river Nile during the Osiris festival at Abydos.

artifacts.name: Hennu
artifacts.description: (also Hennu boat and Henu), the boat of the god Seker. Depending on the era or the prevailing dynasty of Egypt, the Hennu sailed toward either dawn or dusk.

artifacts.name: Argo
artifacts.description: the ship on which Jason and the Argonauts sailed. She contained in her prow a magical piece of timber from the sacred forest of Dodona, which could speak and render prophecies.

artifacts.name: Phaeacian ships
artifacts.description: in the Odyssey, are described as being as fast as a falcon, steered by thought and requiring no helmsman, and able to travel even through mist or fog without any danger of being shipwrecked.

artifacts.name: Charon
artifacts.description: f Charon, which carries souls of the newly deceased across the rivers Styx and Acheron that divided the world of the living from the world of the dead.

artifacts.name: Theseus
artifacts.description: Theseus, the ship Theseus rode on his trip to kill Minotaur. He set off with a black sail, promising to his father, Aegeus, that if successful he would return with a white sail. Theseus forgot to put up the white sails instead of the black ones, however, so Aegeus, believing his son was dead, committed suicide by throwing himself into the sea, leading this body of water to be named Aegean Sea. This ship is more famous as the thought experiment Ship of Theseus.

artifacts.name: dragon ship
artifacts.description: agic dragon ship given to Víking as a gift by Aegir.

artifacts.name: Hringhorni
artifacts.description: the ship of the god Baldr, described as the "greatest of all ships".

artifacts.name: Naglfar
artifacts.description: a ship made out of fingernails and toenails of the dead. It will set sail during Ragnarök.

artifacts.name: Sessrúmnir
artifacts.description: is both the goddess Freyja's hall located in Fólkvangr, a field where Freyja receives half of those who die in battle, and also the name of a ship.

artifacts.name: Skíðblaðnir
artifacts.description: a boat owned by Freyr.

artifacts.name: Ullr
artifacts.description: 's bone, Ullr could traverse the sea on his magic bone.

artifacts.name: The Silver Train of Stockholm
artifacts.description: (Silverpilen, "the Silver Arrow"), a silver colored ghost train said to roam the Stockholm Metro as part of several urban legends. (Swedish folklore)

artifacts.name: St. Louis Ghost Train, visible at night along an old abandoned rail line in between Prince Albert and St. Louis, Saskatchewan. (Canadian legend)
funeral train
artifacts.description: al train, a funeral train decorated in black bunting said to run regularly from Washington, D.C. to Springfield, Illinois, around the anniversary of Abraham Lincoln's death, stopping watches and clocks in surrounding areas as it passes. (American folklore)

artifacts.name: Black triangle
artifacts.description: UFOs reported as having a triangular shape and dark color, typically observed at night, described as large, silent, hovering, moving slowly, and displaying pulsating, colored lights. (Ufology)

artifacts.name: Flying saucer
artifacts.description: (also Flying disc), a supposed type of flying craft having a disc or saucer-shaped body, commonly used generically to refer to an anomalous flying object. (Ufology)

artifacts.name: Foo fighter
artifacts.description: a type of UFO reported and named by the U.S. 415th Special Operations Squadron, the term was also commonly used to mean any UFO sighting from that period. (Ufology)

artifacts.name: Cetiya
artifacts.description: "reminders" or "memorials" (Sanskrit caitya) are objects and places used by Theravada Buddhists to remember Gautama Buddha.

artifacts.name: Relic of the tooth of the Buddha
artifacts.description: venerated in Sri Lanka as a cetiya "relic" of Gautama Buddha, the founder of Buddhism.

artifacts.name: Śarīra
artifacts.description: a generic term referring to Buddhist relics. In Buddhism, relics of the Buddha and various sages are venerated. After the Buddha's death, his remains were divided into eight portions. Afterward, these relics were enshrined in stupas wherever Buddhism was spread.

artifacts.name: Relics of Jesus
artifacts.description: a number of relics associated with Jesus that have been claimed and displayed throughout the history of Christianity.

artifacts.name: Shrine of the Three Kings
artifacts.description: (German Dreikönigsschrein), a reliquary said to contain the bones of the Biblical Magi, also known as the Three Kings or the Three Wise Men.

artifacts.name: Sacred Relics
artifacts.description: (also Holy Relics and Sacred Trust), consist of religious pieces sent to the Ottoman Sultans between the 16th century to the late 19th century.

artifacts.name: Sacred Cloak of the Prophet
artifacts.description: a cloak believed to have been worn by the Islamic prophet Muhammad.

artifacts.name: Aglaophotis
artifacts.description: a herb used for warding off demons, witchcraft, and fever.

artifacts.name: Fern flower
artifacts.description: a magic flower that blooms on the eve of the Summer solstice. It will bring fortune to the person who finds it. (Baltic and Slavic mythology)

artifacts.name: Gaokerena
artifacts.description: was a mythic Haoma plant that had healing properties and gave immortality to the resurrected bodies of the dead when eaten.(Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Hungry grass
artifacts.description: (also Féar Gortach), a patch of cursed grass which causes perpetual and insatiable hunger. (Irish mythology)

artifacts.name: Moly
artifacts.description: a magical herb Hermes gave to Odysseus to protect him from Circe's magic. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Raskovnik
artifacts.description: a magical herb which can unlock or uncover anything that is locked or closed. (Slavic mythology)

artifacts.name: Ashvins
artifacts.description: rdipyamanas, healing plants used for healing and rejuvenations in battles. These are used by Ashvins. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Haoma
artifacts.description: the Avestan language name of a plant and its divinity, both of which play a role in Zoroastrian doctrine and in later Persian culture and mythology. (Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Silphium
artifacts.description: a plant that was used in classical antiquity as a seasoning and as a medicine. Legend said that this plant was a gift from the god Apollo. (Roman mythology)

artifacts.name: Verbena
artifacts.description: a plant which has long been associated with divine and other supernatural forces. It was called "tears of Isis" in ancient Egypt, and later called "Hera's tears". In ancient Greece it was dedicated to Eos Erigineia. In the early Christian era, folk legend stated that V. officinalis was used to staunch Jesus' wounds after his removal from the cross. It was consequently called "holy herb" or (e.g. in Wales) "Devil's bane".

artifacts.name: Yao Grass
artifacts.description: a type of mythical plant. (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Shamrock
artifacts.description: a plant honored as sacred by ancient Druids. The Druids believed the shamrock had the power to avert evil spirits. Some people still believe the shamrock has mystical, even prophetic powers. It is said that the leaves of shamrocks turn upright whenever a storm is coming. (Irish mythology)

artifacts.name: Sanjivani
artifacts.description: a magical herb which can cure any malady. It was believed that medicines prepared from this herb could revive a dead person. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Talking tree
artifacts.description: a form of trees in sapient mythologies and stories. (Worldwide)

artifacts.name: Hōrai
artifacts.description: ed Branch of Hōrai, a branch from a tree found on Hōrai which has jewels for leaves. One of Kaguya-hime's suitors set out to search for the branch. (Japanese mythology)

artifacts.name: Cypress of Kashmar
artifacts.description: a mythical cypress tree of legendary beauty. Iranians considered Kashmir cypress as a relic of Zoroaster, and they believed that Vishtaspa ordered the planting of this cypress after accepting the Zoroastrianism. (Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Ficus Ruminalis
artifacts.description: a wild fig tree that had religious and mythological significance in ancient Rome. The tree is associated with the legend of Romulus and Remus. (Roman mythology)

artifacts.name: Donar's Oak
artifacts.description: (also Thor's Oak and Jove's Oak), a sacred tree of the Germanic pagans located in what is now the region of Hesse, Germany. (Germanic mythology)

artifacts.name: Silver Branch
artifacts.description: a tree that represents entry into the Celtic Otherworld. It is also associated with Manannán mac Lir, an Irish sea deity with strong affiliation to Tír na nÓg. As guardian of the Otherworld, Manannán also has strong ties with Emhain Abhlach, the Isle of Apple Trees, where the magical silver apple branch is found. (Irish mythology)

artifacts.name: Lotus tree
artifacts.description: bearing a fruit that caused drowsiness, and which was said to be the only food of an island people called the Lotophagi or Lotus-eaters. When they ate of the lotus tree they would forget their friends and homes and would lose the desire to return to their native land in favor of living in idleness. (Greek mythology/Roman mythology)

artifacts.name: Money tree
artifacts.description: a holy tree which can bring money and fortune to the people, and is a symbol of affluence, nobility and auspiciousness. (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Tree of life
artifacts.description: a tree planted in the middle of the Garden of Eden and guarded by cherubim. (Christian mythology/Jewish mythology)

artifacts.name: Tree of the knowledge of good and evil
artifacts.description: one of two trees in the story of the Garden of Eden, along with the tree of life. (Christian mythology/Jewish mythology)

artifacts.name: Golden Bough
artifacts.description: before entering Hades, Deiphobe tells Aeneas he must obtain the bough of gold which grows nearby in the woods around her cave, and must be given as a gift to Proserpina, the queen of Pluto, king of the underworld. (Roman mythology)

artifacts.name: Zaqqum (Zakum)
artifacts.description: a vile tree that grows in the depths of Jahannam (Hell). (Islamic mythology)

artifacts.name: Nariphon
artifacts.description: a tree which bears fruit in the shape of young female creatures. (Buddhist mythology)

artifacts.name: Barnstokkr
artifacts.description: (Child-trunk), a tree that stands in the center of King Völsung's hall.

artifacts.name: Glasir
artifacts.description: (Gleaming), a tree or grove described as "the most beautiful among gods and men", bearing golden leaves located in the realm of Asgard, outside the doors of Valhalla.

artifacts.name: Læraðr
artifacts.description: a tree that is often identified with Yggdrasil. It stands at the top of the Valhöll. Two animals, the goat Heiðrún and the hart Eikþyrnir, graze its foliage.

artifacts.name: Mímameiðr
artifacts.description: (Mimi's Tree), a tree whose branches stretch over every land, is unharmed by fire or metal, bears fruit that assists pregnant women, and upon whose highest bough roosts the rooster Víðópnir.

artifacts.name: Sacred tree at Uppsala
artifacts.description: a sacred tree located at the Temple at Uppsala, Sweden, in the second half of the 11th century. It is not known what species it was, but a scholar has suggested that it was a yew tree.

artifacts.name: Yggdrasil
artifacts.description: an immense tree that connects the nine worlds. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Sefirot
artifacts.description: (counting, enumeration) the kabbalistic tree of life which encompasses both the physical and higher metaphysical realm. It consists of the ten attributes/emanations in Kabbalah. (Jewish mythology)

artifacts.name: Irminsul
artifacts.description: (Great/Mighty Pillar or Arising Pillar), a pillar which is attested as playing an important role in the Germanic paganism of the Saxon people. The oldest chronicle describing an Irminsul refers to it as a tree trunk erected in the open air. (Germanic mythology)

artifacts.name: Égig érő fa
artifacts.description: (Sky-high Tree), also called Életfa (Tree of Life), Világfa (World Tree), or Tetejetlen Fa (Tree Without a Top), is an element of Hungarian shamanism and native faith, and a typical element of Hungarian folk art and folk tales, and also a distinct folk tale type. (Hungarian mythology)

artifacts.name: Akshayavat
artifacts.description: or Akshay Vat (Indestructible Banyan Tree), is a sacred fig tree. The sage Markandeya asked Lord Narayana to show him a specimen of the divine power. Narayana flooded the entire world for a moment, during which only the Akshayavat could be seen above the water level. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Kalpavriksha
artifacts.description: (also Kalpataru, Kalpadruma or Kalpapādapa), a wish-fulfilling divine tree. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Ashvattha
artifacts.description: (also Assattha), a sacred tree for the Hindus and has been extensively mentioned in texts pertaining to Hinduism, mentioned as 'peepul' (Ficus religiosa) in Rig Veda mantra I.164.20 . Buddhist texts term the tree as Bodhi tree, a tree under which Gautam Buddha meditated and gained enlightenment. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Turkic mythology
artifacts.description: rld tree is a central symbol. According to the Altai Turks, human beings are descended from trees. According to the Yakuts, White Mother sits at the base of Ağaç Ana, whose branches reach to the heavens where it is occupied by various creatures that have come to life there. The blue sky around the tree reflects the peaceful nature of the country and the red ring that surrounds all of the elements symbolizes the ancient faith of rebirth, growth and development of the Turkic peoples. (Turkic mythology)

artifacts.name: Mongolian mythology
artifacts.description: ee. (Mongolian mythology)

artifacts.name: Mesoamerican world tree
artifacts.description: the world trees embodied the four cardinal directions, which also serve to represent the fourfold nature of a central world tree, a symbolic axis mundi which connects the planes of the Underworld and the sky with that of the terrestrial realm. (Mesoamerican mythology)

artifacts.name: Austras koks
artifacts.description: (Tree of Dawn), on the path of the sun, in or by the water, often on an island or rock in middle of the seas, is the Austras koks thought to represent world tree or axis mundi, it is usually described as a tree, but can also be variety of other plants or even objects. (Latvian mythology)

artifacts.name: Finnic mythologies
artifacts.description: e)/Életfa (Tree of Life), the world tree connects different realities; the underworld, this world, and the upper world together. A shaman was believed to be able to climb through each of these levels freely by a ladder. (Finnic mythologies)

artifacts.name: Ambrosia
artifacts.description: the food or drink of the gods, which gives longevity or immortality to whoever consumes it. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Amrita
artifacts.description: the drink of the gods which grants them immortality. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Mead of poetry
artifacts.description: (also Mead of Suttungr), a mythical beverage that whoever "drinks becomes a skald or scholar to recite any information and solve any question. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Soma
artifacts.description: it is described as being prepared by extracting juice from the stalks of a certain plant. In both Vedic and Zoroastrian tradition, the name of the drink and the plant are the same, and also personified as a divinity, the three forming a religious or mythological unity. (Zoroastrian mythology)

artifacts.name: Apple of Discord
artifacts.description: (also Golden Apple of Discord), the goddess Eris inscribed "to the fairest" and tossed in the midst of the festivities at the wedding of Peleus and Thetis. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Forbidden fruit
artifacts.description: eaten by Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden, which they had been commanded not to do by God. (Christian mythology/Jewish mythology)

artifacts.name: Golden apple
artifacts.description: an element that appears in various national and ethnic folk legends or fairy tales.

artifacts.name: Peaches of Immortality
artifacts.description: consumed by the immortals due to their mystic virtue of conferring longevity on all who eat them. (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Pomegranate
artifacts.description: (also Fruit of the Dead in Greek mythology), believed to have sprung from the blood of Adonis. It was the rule of the Moirai that anyone who consumed food or drink in the underworld had to spend eternity there. Persephone ate six pomegranate seeds while in the Underworld after becoming Hades' wife, so she had to spend six months in the underworld every year. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Emhain Abhlach
artifacts.description: magical silver apples can be found on Emhain Abhlach, the Isle of Apple Trees. (Irish mythology)

artifacts.name: Poison apple, featured frequently in folktales or fairy tales.
Orichalcum
artifacts.description: a metal that was considered second only to gold in value, and was mined in Atlantis in ancient times.

artifacts.name: Panacea
artifacts.description: a remedy that would cure all diseases and prolong life indefinitely.

artifacts.name: Lethe
artifacts.description: of Lethe, which flows through the river Lethe, and causes those who drink it to experience forgetfulness.

artifacts.name: Aether
artifacts.description: the pure essence that the gods breathed, filling the space where they lived, analogous to the air breathed by mortals.

artifacts.name: Miasma
artifacts.description: "a contagious power... that has an independent life of its own. Until purged by the sacrificial death of the wrongdoer, society would be chronically infected by catastrophe".

artifacts.name: Kykeon
artifacts.description: ancient Greek drink of various descriptions used at the climax of the Eleusinian Mysteries.

artifacts.name: Pneuma
artifacts.description: a supernatural substance that is present in all souls and sustains life in all breathing living creatures. Thought of as giving cosmic energy through breath. One main components of the parts of the soul in ancient Greek medicine.

artifacts.name: Atter
artifacts.description: a liquid substance that is the origin of all living things, and is produced by Jörmungandr and other serpents.

artifacts.name: Surtr
artifacts.description: logi (Surtr's fire), the fire with which the giant Surtr will burn the world with fire, thus destroying it.

artifacts.name: Yggdrasil
artifacts.description: dew, dew that falls from the ash tree Yggdrasil. When Líf and Lífþrasir seek refuge within Yggdrasil, they find that they can survive there by drinking the dew of Yggdrasil.

artifactSubCategories.subCategoryTitle: Substances from Medieval legend and European folklore

artifacts.name: Adamant
artifacts.description: (also Adamantine), a hard substance, whether composed of diamond, some other gemstone, or some type of metal.

artifacts.name: Alkahest
artifacts.description: a hypothetical universal solvent which can dissolve every other substance, including gold. It was much sought after by alchemists for what they thought would be its invaluable medicinal qualities. (Medieval legend)

artifacts.name: Azoth
artifacts.description: a universal medicine or universal solvent sought in alchemy. (Medieval legend)

artifacts.name: Cold iron
artifacts.description: is historically believed to repel, contain, or harm ghosts, fairies, witches, and/or other malevolent supernatural creatures. (European folklore)

artifacts.name: Elixir of life
artifacts.description: a mythical potion that, when drunk from a certain cup at a certain time, supposedly grants the drinker eternal life and/or eternal youth. (Medieval legend)

artifacts.name: fairy ring
artifacts.description: fairy ring are circles of mushrooms that seem to pop-up over night in yards. It is said to grow from the magic dust left behind by faeries as they danced and celebrated during the night, before returning to their hidden land. (English folklore)

artifacts.name: Four Thieves Vinegar
artifacts.description: a concoction of vinegar infused with herbs,spices or garlic that was believed to protect the user from the plague (disease). (European folklore)

artifacts.name: Holy water
artifacts.description: believed to ward off or act as a weapon against mythical evil creatures, such as vampires. In eastern Europe, one might sprinkle holy water onto the corpse of a suspected vampire to destroy it or render it inert. (European folklore)

artifacts.name: Tristan
artifacts.description: tion, Tristan goes to Ireland to bring back Isolde the fair for his uncle King Mark to marry. Along the way, they ingest a love potion which causes the pair to fall madly in love. (Arthurian legend)

artifacts.name: Prima materia
artifacts.description: (also Materia Prima or First Matter), is the ubiquitous starting material required for the alchemical magnum opus and the creation of the philosopher's stone. It is the primitive formless base of all matter similar to chaos, the quintessence, or aether. (Medieval legend)

artifacts.name: Sandman
artifacts.description: 's sand, which the Sandman uses to put people to sleep and bring good dreams by sprinkling it into their eyes while they sleep. (European folklore)

artifacts.name: Yliaster
artifacts.description: is the formless base of all matter which is the raw material for the alchemical Great Work. (Medieval legend)

artifacts.name: Unspoken Water
artifacts.description: water believed to have healing properties when collected "from under a bridge, over which the living pass and the dead are carried, brought in the dawn or twilight to the house of a sick person, without the bearer's speaking, either in going or returning". (Scottish folklore)

artifacts.name: Fountain of Youth
artifacts.description: ter from the Fountain of Youth that supposedly restores the youth of anyone who drinks or bathes in its waters. (Medieval legend)

artifacts.name: east of the sun and west of the moon
artifacts.description: who lives in a castle east of the sun and west of the moon gives the prince a sleeping drink, so that the youngest daughter cannot wake him. (Scandinavian folklore)

artifacts.name: Teonanácatl
artifacts.description: in Nahuatl literally "god mushroom"—compound of the words teo(tl) (god) and nanácatl (mushroom).

artifacts.name: Emperor Jimmu
artifacts.description: escribed in the apocryphal Takenouchi Document, an alleged ancient writing in a lost script which details Japan's early history, Hihīrokane was used in the time of Emperor Jimmu, Japan's first emperor. The Kusanagi-no-tsurugi and the other Imperial Regalia of Japan are supposedly made from it. Its weight is lighter than gold, but harder than diamond. It was even said to be able to bring water to a boil without heat, violating the Law of Conservation of Energy. (Japanese mythology)

artifacts.name: Hiranyagarbha
artifacts.description: the source of the creation of the universe or the manifested cosmos. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Halahala
artifacts.description: a poison created from the sea when the gods and demons churned it to obtain Amrita, the nectar of immortality. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Prana
artifacts.description: is all cosmic energy, permeating the Universe on all levels. Prana is often referred to as the "life force" or "life energy". It also includes energies present in inanimate objects. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Meng Po
artifacts.description: avored Tea of Forgetfulness,a brew created by Meng Po that is given to each soul to drink before they leave Diyu. The brew induces instant and permanent amnesia, and all memory of other lives is lost. (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Qi
artifacts.description: (also Chi or Ki), an active principle forming part of any living thing. Qi literally translates as "breath", "air", or "gas", and figuratively as "material energy", "life force", or "energy flow". Qi is the central underlying principle in traditional Chinese medicine and martial arts. (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Chakra
artifacts.description: an energy point or node in the subtle body. Chakras are believed to be part of the subtle body, not the physical body, and as such, are the meeting points of the subtle (non-physical) energy channels called Nadi. (Hinduism/Jainism/Buddhism)

artifacts.name: Yin and yang
artifacts.description: a concept of dualism, describing how seemingly opposite or contrary forces may actually be complementary, interconnected, and interdependent in the natural world, and how they may give rise to each other as they interrelate to one another. (Chinese mythology)

artifacts.name: Satyaki
artifacts.description: ardhanam, the conch shell of Satyaki. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Panchajanya
artifacts.description: a Shankha conch shell of the Hindu god Vishnu. As per Valmiki Ramyana, Purushottama (Vishnu) killed a Danava named Panchajana on a mountain named Chakravan constructed by Vishwakarma and took away conch shell known as Panchajanya from him. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Shankha
artifacts.description: a conch shell and sacred emblem of the Hindu preserver god Vishnu. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Triton
artifacts.description: 's conch shell, a twisted conch shell on which Triton blew like a trumpet to calm or raise the waves. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Drake's Drum
artifacts.description: a snare drum that Sir Francis Drake took with him when he circumnavigated the world. Shortly before he died he ordered the drum to be taken to Buckland Abbey and vowed that if England was ever in danger and someone was to beat the drum he would return to defend the country. According to legend it can be heard to beat at times when England is at war or significant national events take place. (English folklore)

artifacts.name: Cultrun
artifacts.description: a Mapuche drum that the Machi's use for healing. (Chilean mythology)

artifacts.name: pan flute
artifacts.description: te, reed pipes or pan flute that is played by the god of the wild, Pan. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Pied Piper
artifacts.description: 's magic pipe, which the Pied Piper used to lure the rats, and later children, out of Hamelin. (German folklore)

artifacts.name: Bragi
artifacts.description: 's harp, a magical golden harp given to Bragi by the dwarfs when he was born. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: David
artifacts.description: 's harp (also Kinnor David), a harp hung above King David's bed, and precisely at midnight a north wind arrived and blew on the harp and it would play by itself. (Jewish mythology)

artifacts.name: Kantele
artifacts.description: the mage Väinämöinen makes the first kantele from the jawbone of a giant pike and a few hairs from Hiisi's stallion. The music it makes draws all the forest creatures near to wonder at its beauty. (Finnish mythology)

artifacts.name: Uaithne
artifacts.description: (also Dur da Blá, The Oak of Two Blossoms, and Coir Cethar Chuin), the harp which belongs to The Dagda. After the Second Battle of Mag Tuired the Fomorians had taken The Dagda's harp with them. The Dagda found it in a feasting-house wherein Bres and his father Elathan were also. The Dagda had bound the music so that it would not sound until he would call to it. After he called to it, it sprang from the wall, came to the Dagda and killed nine men on its way. (Irish mythology)

artifacts.name: Binnorie
artifacts.description: 's harp (also Minnorie's harp), when the murdered girl's body floats ashore, a musician made a musical instrument out of it, a harp, with a frame of bone and the girl's "long yellow hair" for strings. The instrument then plays itself and sings about the murder. (Northumbrian folklore)

artifacts.name: Lyra
artifacts.description: n Arthur (Arthur's Harp), the name of the constellation of Lyra in Wales. (Welsh mythology)

artifacts.name: Canola's harp
artifacts.description: (Cana's Harp), Canola realised the wind had created the music by blowing through partially rotted sinew still attached to a whale skeleton. She designed the harp based on this. (Irish mythology)

artifacts.name: Gabriel
artifacts.description: Gabriel, a horn blown by the Archangel Gabriel to announce Judgement Day. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Olifant
artifacts.description: (also Olivant), the horn of Roland, paladin of Charlemagne in the Song of Roland. Roland blows the horn, but the force required bursts his temple, resulting in death. His olifant was supposedly a unicorn's horn. (Matter of France)

artifacts.name: Gjallarhorn
artifacts.description: a mystical horn blown at the onset of Ragnarök associated with the god Heimdallr and the wise being Mímir. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Amphion
artifacts.description: 's lyre, a gift to Amphion from his lover Hermes that allowed Amphion to telekinetically move stones to build the walls of Thebes. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Hermes
artifacts.description: 's lyre, Hermes created the lyre for him from the entrails of one of Apollo's cows. Apollo was furious at Hermes, but after hearing the sound of the lyre, his anger faded. The instrument became a common attribute of Apollo. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Apollo
artifacts.description: s' lyre, a golden lyre given to him by Apollo. It is said that Orpheus' music and singing could charm the birds, fish and wild beasts, coax the trees and rocks into dance, and divert the course of rivers. It is state that his lyre was placed in the sky by Zeus. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Sistrum
artifacts.description: one of the most sacred musical instruments in ancient Egypt, which was believed to hold powerful magical properties. It was also shaken to avert the flooding of the Nile and to frighten away Set. (Egyptian mythology)

artifacts.name: Seven trumpets
artifacts.description: seven angels with seven trumpets are sounded and the events that follow are described in detail from Revelation Chapters 8 to 11. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Zahhak
artifacts.description: trumpets of Zahhak, Seven golden trumpets, each of which was connected to one of the seven realms of the world, and by blowing each of those trumpets, Zahhak would send down deadly disasters such as plagues, earthquakes, and rain of fire on that land. (Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Pheme
artifacts.description: 's trumpet, Pheme is the goddess of gossip and she was said to have pried into the affairs of mortals and gods. She then repeated what she had learned by sounding her trumpet to spread the gossip to people near and far. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Joshua
artifacts.description: 's shofars (also Joshua's trumpets), the walls of Jericho fell after Joshua's Israelite army marched around the city blowing their trumpets during the Battle of Jericho. (Jewish mythology)

artifacts.name: Brazen head
artifacts.description: (also brass head or bronze head), a legendary automaton reputed to be able to answer any question. (Medieval legend)

artifacts.name: Mímir
artifacts.description: 's head, the severed head of Mimir, which was magically preserved by Odin so it could continue to provide knowledge and counsel as his advisor. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Medusa
artifacts.description: 's head, the severed head of Medusa, which was given to Athena by Perseus to place on her Aegis. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Ymir
artifacts.description: 's skull, Norðri, Suðri, Austri and Vestri each support one of the four cardinal points. Together, they uphold the heavenly dome, created from the skull of the jötunn Ymir. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Bendigeidfran
artifacts.description: 's head, the severed head of Brân the Blessed, which was buried in London facing France to magically ward off invasion. (Welsh mythology)

artifacts.name: Odin
artifacts.description: 's eye, Odin sacrifice his eye to Mímir for the price of wisdom, a drink from the Mímisbrunnr. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Eye of Horus
artifacts.description: Set and Horus were fighting for the throne after Osiris's death, Set gouged out Horus's left eye. The majority of the eye was restored by Thoth. When Horus's eye was recovered, he offered it to his father, Osiris, in hopes of restoring his life. (Egyptian mythology)

artifacts.name: Graeae
artifacts.description: 's eye, three sisters who shared one eye among themselves. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Eye of Ra
artifacts.description: Ra was becoming old and weak and the people no longer respected him or his rule. Ra did not react well to this and decided to punish mankind by sending his Eye to find them. (Egyptian mythology)

artifacts.name: Balor
artifacts.description: 's eye, a large eye that wreaks destruction when opened. The Cath Maige Tuired calls it a "destructive" and "poisonous" eye that no army can withstand. (Irish mythology)

artifacts.name: Eye of Providence
artifacts.description: a symbol showing an eye often surrounded by rays of light or a glory and usually enclosed by a triangle. It represents the eye of God watching over mankind or divine providence.

artifacts.name: Þjazi
artifacts.description: 's eyes, Odin took Þjazi's eyes and placed them in the night sky as stars. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Shiva
artifacts.description: 's third eye, it could burn even gods to ashes. (Hindu mythology)

artifacts.name: Hand of Glory
artifacts.description: a severed pickled hand of a man who was hanged alive. Said to have the power to unlock any door and, if a candle was placed within made from some body part of the same person, would freeze in place anyone who it was given to. (European folklore)

artifacts.name: Týr
artifacts.description: 's hand, which was bitten off by Fenrir. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Hand of God
artifacts.description: (also Manus Dei and Dextera domini/dei), ", a motif in Jewish and Christian art, especially of the Late Antique and early medieval periods, when depiction of Jehovah or God the Father as a full human figure was considered unacceptable. The hand, sometimes including a portion of an arm, or ending about the wrist, is used to indicate the intervention in or approval of affairs on Earth by God, and sometimes as a subject in itself. (Christian mythology/Jewish mythology)

artifacts.name: Thor
artifacts.description: andils-tá (Aurvandill's toe), the god Thor tosses Aurvandill's toe which had frozen into the sky to form a star called Aurvandils-tá. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Golden Fleece
artifacts.description: sought by Jason and the Argonauts. The fleece of the golden winged ram, which was sought by Jason and the Argonauts. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Firebird
artifacts.description: 's plumage, the feathers of a Firebird that glows brightly emitting red, orange, and yellow light, like a bonfire that is just past the turbulent flame. The feathers do not cease glowing if removed, and one feather can light a large room if not concealed. (Slavic mythology)

artifacts.name: Simurgh
artifacts.description: s of Simurgh, the legendary Simurgh gave three of her feathers to Zal, the Persian hero and also father of Rostam, so that whenever he needed the guidance or help of Simurgh, he could burn one of the feathers and Simurgh came to his aid. (Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Aaru
artifacts.description: her of Ma'at (also Feather of Truth), her ostrich feather was the measure that determined whether the souls of the departed would reach the fields of Aaru successfully. The hearts of the dead were said to be weighed against her single feather in the Hall of Two Truths. (Egyptian mythology)

artifacts.name: Peacock
artifacts.description: 's feather, the peacock was the patron bird of the Goddess Hera. According to myth, she adorned the tail of a peacock with Argus's eyes on its feathers in his honor, symbolizing all-seeing knowledge and the wisdom of the heavens. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Leviathan
artifacts.description: 's hide, could be turned into everlasting clothing or impenetrable suits of armor. (Jewish mythology)

artifacts.name: Nemean lion
artifacts.description: 's hide, the lion could not be killed with mortal weapons because its golden fur was impervious to attacks. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Selkie
artifacts.description: 's skin, selkies are said to live as seals in the sea but shed their skin to become human on land. If a man steals a female selkie's skin, she is in his power and is forced to become his wife. If she finds her skin she will return to her true home in the sea. (European folklore)

artifacts.name: Coma Berenices
artifacts.description: (Berenice's hair), Berenice II of Egypt dedicated her hair to Aphrodite for her husband's safe return from Syria, and placed it in the temple of the goddess at Zephyrium. The hair had been carried to the heavens and placed among the stars. (Egyptian mythology)

artifacts.name: Ymir
artifacts.description: 's hair, Odin, Vili and Vé used his hair for the trees. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Ymir
artifacts.description: 's eyebrows , Odin, Vili and Vé used his eyebrows to create the middle realm in which humans live, Midgard. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Hydra
artifacts.description: 's poisonous blood, Heracles would use arrows dipped in the Hydra's poisonous blood to kill other foes during his Labours, such as Stymphalian birds and the giant Geryon. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Ningyo
artifacts.description: 's flesh, the flesh is pleasant-tasting and anyone who eats it will attain remarkable longevity. (Japanese mythology)

artifacts.name: Fafnir
artifacts.description: 's blood, Sigurd bathed in dragon's blood that conferred him invulnerability. He also drank some of Fafnir's blood and gained the ability to understand the language of the birds. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Blood of Christ
artifacts.description: the blood shed by Jesus Christ on the Cross. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Ichor
artifacts.description: the ethereal golden fluid that is the blood of the gods. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Ymir
artifacts.description: 's flesh, Odin, Vili and Vé fashioned the Earth from his flesh. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Ymir
artifacts.description: 's blood, Odin, Vili and Vé used his blood to form the ocean. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Unicorn horn
artifacts.description: (also Alicorn), the detached horn of a unicorn was thought to have many healing properties and antidote's virtues were attributed to the unicorn's horn. (European folklore)

artifacts.name: Dragon's teeth
artifacts.description: in the legends of the Phoenician prince Cadmus and in Jason's quest for the Golden Fleece. In each case, the dragons are real and breathe fire. Their teeth, once planted, would grow into fully armed warriors. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Camahueto
artifacts.description: 's horn, the most valuable part of a Camahueto is their single horn, machis will use the horn for curing many kinds of illnesses. (Chilote mythology)

artifacts.name: Ymir
artifacts.description: 's bones, Odin, Vili and Vé used his bones the make the hills. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Valknut
artifacts.description: (also Hrungnir's Heart), Hrungnir's head, heart, and shield were made of stone. His heart had a peculiar shape, it was triangular due to which both the Valknut and the Triquetra have been called Hrungnir's heart. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Fafnir
artifacts.description: 's heart, which was roasted and consumed by Sigurd, giving him the gift of prophecy. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Ymir
artifacts.description: 's brain, which was used by Odin, Vili and Vé to make the clouds. (Norse mythology)

artifacts.name: Uranus
artifacts.description: 's genitals, which fell on the ocean and formed Aphrodite, a nymph who later on became the goddess of beauty after being introduced to at Olympus (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: creation of the world
artifacts.description: pouch containing the secrets that were supposed to be the reward of the spirit responsible for the creation of the world. It was originally given by Olorun to Obatala, who was mandated by Him to serve that function, but was subsequently stolen by his brother/sister/spouse Oduduwa when he/she usurped his position as creator spirit. This and the simultaneous theft of the Basket of Existence (see above) later led to a war between them. (Yoruba mythology)

artifacts.name: Aeolus
artifacts.description: Wind, Aeolus gave Odysseus a tightly closed leather bag full of the captured winds so he could sail easily home to Ithaca on the gentle West Wind. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Corrbolg
artifacts.description: a bag crafted by Manannán mac Lir from the skin of Aoife who had been transformed into a crane at the time of her death. It was later given to Conaire Mór and then eventually to Cumhall mac Trénmhóir. The crane bag contained a variable amount of items depending on if the tide was high or low. (Irish mythology)

artifacts.name: Maitreya
artifacts.description: Dai, one of the ten ancient artifacts, the universe bag or cosmos bag is a bag belonging to Maitreya that is able to fit all of heaven and earth inside. (Chinese Mythology)

artifacts.name: Perseus
artifacts.description: the sack in which the mythical hero Perseus carried the severed head of the monster Medusa. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Santa
artifacts.description: 's bag, carries a bag full of presents for children. (Modern folklore)

artifacts.name: Cup of Jamshid
artifacts.description: (Jām-e Jam), a cup of divination that was long possessed by rulers of ancient Persia and was said to be filled with an elixir of immortality. (Persian mythology)

artifacts.name: Nanteos Cup
artifacts.description: a medieval wood mazer bowl attributed with the ability to heal those who drink from it. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Holy Grail
artifacts.description: a dish, plate, stone, or cup that is part of an important theme of Arthurian literature. (Arthurian legend/Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Holy Chalice
artifacts.description: the vessel which Jesus used at the Last Supper to serve the wine. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Crater
artifacts.description: (Cup), identified with the cup of the god Apollo. (Greek mythology)

artifacts.name: Seven bowls
artifacts.description: seven angels are thus given seven bowls of God's wrath, each consisting of judgements full of the wrath of God. These seven bowls of God's wrath are poured out on the wicked and the followers of the Antichrist after the sounding of the seven trumpets. (Christian mythology)

artifacts.name: Diogenes
artifacts.description: of Diogenes, carried by the Cynic philosopher Diogenes of Sinope to aid in his fruitless search for an honest man. (Greek philosophy)

artifacts.name: oil lamp
artifacts.description: mp, an oil lamp that can be rubbed to summon a genie who grants wishes. (Arabic mythology)
